HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: VOICES; 
Divided Over Another War, But Still on Speaking Terms

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Across Fifth Avenue from an antiwar demonstration yesterday in Manhattan, Steve Durgee, 33, brandished an American flag and a sign that read "Move to France (please!)." Speeding by on Rollerblades, Roger Manning, 46, said, "You people are fools!"
 The two men started to yell at each other, then to argue, then to talk. No minds were changed, but in a few minutes the long-haired Mr. Manning and the short-haired Mr. Durgee were saying things like, "I have no problem with discussion," and "Good point." 
 Americans may not agree on the wisdom of going to war with Iraq, but polls and interviews around New York suggest that the two sides remain on speaking terms. While each side views the other as misguided, so far relatively few are voicing the vitriol about each other that characterized the last period of division over an American war. 
Thirty years ago, after a decade of escalating war in Vietnam, slogans like "America, Love It or Leave It" carried an angry punch. This time, the mantra of many New Yorkers seems to be, "Everyone is entitled to his own opinion."
Take Michael Pearson, a 35-year-old carpenter who lives in Long Island City, Queens. He supports President Bush, he said, and thinks the antiwar protests have been counterproductive. But asked if these demonstrations should be permitted, he sounded almost incredulous.
"Oh, of course they should be able to protest, without a doubt," he said. "That's what we're fighting for."
Thirty-three years ago, construction workers beat up antiwar demonstrators on Wall Street and stormed City Hall. Four students were killed by the National Guard during a period of antiwar protests at Kent State. Families feuded over the dinner table. One 1970 Harris poll found that 37 percent of Americans thought that protests against the Vietnam War should be illegal.
Today, 61 percent say Americans who oppose the war should be allowed to hold protest marches and rallies, while 29 percent think that such activity is detrimental to the war effort, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll, based on telephone interviews conducted Sunday and Monday with 1,032 adults nationwide, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Of course, just because you believe people can protest does not mean you believe that they should. "Once the war started, you should not protest anymore," said Salvatore Scarlato, 70, of Hauppauge, in Suffolk County, who is a veteran of the Korean War. "You should now say, 'Let's support our troops and hope it's over soon.' "
And it is not hard to find war-related nastiness and name-calling (and not just on talk radio).
At the Fifth Avenue antiwar demonstration yesterday morning, outside Rockefeller Center, hecklers called protesters "traitors" and "freaks" and yelled "Get a job!" at young people in the crowd. The protesters in turn called those who disagreed with them "idiots" and tried to drown out dissent by chanting "Peace is patriotic."
The size of the crowd was hard to gauge because there were so many reporters, camera crews, uniformed police officers, plainclothes officers, tourists, kibitzers and people just trying to get to work. Several dozen protesters knocked over police barricades and lay down on Fifth Avenue, closing the road for about 16 minutes. Scattered protests continued during the day; the police said 215 people were arrested.
Those who have studied the Vietnam protests and those who participated in them have several explanations for why discourse may be more civil now. One is simply that these are still the early days of the war.
Disruptive demonstrations can wear out even the most tolerant. And more American casualties could easily harden the positions of both antiwar protesters and those who believe that the most important thing is to support the troops and their commander in chief.
But unlike the Vietnam-era protesters, demonstrators these days have been careful to express their admiration for those serving in the armed forces, and to avoid, for the most part, desecrating American flags. "Everyone is trying to grab the patriotic banner," said Christian G. Appy, whose "Patriots: The Vietnam War Remembered From All Sides," will be published by Viking in May.
Not having a draft may also help defuse some of the class-based resentments that made the Vietnam protests so unpopular with many Americans, especially blue-collar families whose sons were serving overseas. "Working-class people were as divided by the war as anyone else," Mr. Appy said, "but they were deeply offended by upper-middle-class protesters who had all of the advantages."
Antiwar protests have also become an accepted part of American history and culture, said Seymour Melman, emeritus professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University and a speaker at an antiwar protest on Wall Street in 1970.
"Present populations are drawing upon a common heritage of ideas that has been around for some time," he said.
And the antiwar movement today appears more diverse than it was during the early protests of the Vietnam War, when it often seemed hostile to "anyone over 30."
Joy Seldin, 55, of Montclair, N.J., said that when she and her friends were protesting the Vietnam War, "our parents all thought that we were traitors." Now, she said, she and her daughter oppose the war -- and so does her 76-year-old mother in Florida.
Mrs. Seldin has not been to any of the recent protests (except in spirit), but William Nunziata has. And they are different from those he attended during the Vietnam era, said Mr. Nunziata, 51, a transit worker who works in Queens. 
"Because this protest is not just hippies -- I am a hippie by the way," he said. "The construction workers were with us on the line."
Many people, in New York and elsewhere, find themselves in ambiguous positions, opposing the war, supporting the troops, hating Saddam Hussein, wishing the United Nations had backed the United States, worrying about terrorism, fretting about the amount of money the war will cost and what it will do to the economy.
Jeff Wilkins, a businessman from Los Gatos, Calif., who was visiting ground zero, ran through many of these thoughts, and more, when asked what he thought of the war. As for the protesters, he said: "People have opinions and they need to express them, especially extreme opinions, and there's nothing more extreme than life and death. But I'm ashamed our soldiers don't have support."
When he listens to both sides, he said, "it's difficult to agree with everything, and it's difficult to disagree with everything."
But even those who know most definitely where they stand can often be understanding, at least in public, about those who disagree.
Rabbi Dr. Tzvi Hersh Weinreb of the Orthodox Union, who attended a Tuesday evening prayer service on the Upper West Side in support of the troops, firmly backs the American effort in Iraq.
Still, he said of the demonstrators, "that's what we are fighting for, the right to dissent." While he thinks they are misguided about how peace can be achieved, he said, "I don't think they are misguided in terms of being off the wall."
At the other end of the political spectrum is Maya Sen, an organizer with the antiwar group Not in Our Name, one of the groups involved in yesterday's protest. But she, too, kept her rhetoric cool in discussing the war's supporters. "I think they are misinformed, notgetting the whole picture, not being provided with the complete truth," she said.
But, she added, "there are a lot of people with very good intentions on both sides."

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES 

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr

 BODY:
Oscar Gold For New York
 Sunday night's Oscar ceremonies were another triumph for New York-based distributors, but it wasn't just the studio-owned specialty divisions, like Miramax ("Chicago"), Focus Features ("The Pianist") and Sony Pictures Classics ("Talk to Her") that brought home little gold men. 
 Zeitgeist Films, a tiny, truly independent art film distributor based in a walk-up suite of offices in a SoHo loft building, found itself the beneficiary of a best foreign-language film award for "Nowhere in Africa." Directed by Caroline Link, this German production, about a Jewish family that flees Nazi persecution by immigrating to Kenya, was acquired by Zeitgeist in November 2001 for the American market.
"We had heard from a lot of people that 'Nowhere in Africa' had a good chance for the Oscar," said Nancy Gerstman, who founded Zeitgeist with Emily Russo in 1988. "We felt as confident as you can feel, but you never know." 
Ms. Russo said: "We borrowed a loft for the occasion, and we just did it up for our staff and our families. We didn't know what the outcome was going to be, but we were ready for anything."
Ms. Gerstman added: "We've been in business for 15 years, and we've really worked just unbelievably hard. It's so nice to have this happen now." Zeitgeist's earlier successes were Todd Haynes's "Poison" and Abbas Kiarostami's "Taste of Cherry."
The Zeitgeist staff could not attend the ceremonies in Los Angeles because the small number of tickets allotted to the foreign language nominees went to the film's German producers. As it turned out, even Ms. Link, the film's writer and director, wasn't able to go because of a family emergency. "Her baby had been sick in the hospital," Ms. Gerstman said, "and she didn't feel that she should leave Germany." Salma Hayek, who presented the foreign language award, accepted on Ms. Link's behalf.
What's the immediate effect of an Oscar? "It's opening much wider this week," Ms. Russo said. "We'll be on 33 screens on Friday, in all of the major markets." (In New York City, the film will continue at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas and the BAM Rose Cinemas in Brooklyn while adding the Quad Cinema in Greenwich Village.)
It's the widest opening in Zeitgeist's history, and the company's founders are thrilled. "We're ready, we're up for it, we've been waiting for it," Ms. Gerstman and Ms. Russo exclaimed, speaking over each other in a simultaneous burst of enthusiasm.

A Range of Roles
Ever since Neil LaBute cast his old college friend Aaron Eckhart as the breathtakingly cruel junior executive in Mr. LaBute's debut film, "In the Company of Men," Mr. Eckhart has become a familiar figure in independent films. With his matinee-idol good looks -- he has one of the few cleft chins to appear in the movies since Cary Grant and Kirk Douglas -- and his willingness to take chances with unsympathetic roles, Mr. Eckhart has proved himself an actor of unusual range and unusual courage.
But in Jon Amiel's fantasy adventure "The Core," which opens nationally today (review, Page 1 of Weekend), Mr. Eckhart has struck out in a surprising new direction: the mainstream. "I just wanted to play a character the whole family could go see, you know?" Mr. Eckhart said by phone from Arizona, where he has just completed filming Ron Howard's western "The Missing." "Something that was not so controversial. I like this movie because it's PG-13 and just a fun ride."
"I've always said about Neil that he could flourish in any genre," Mr. Eckhart said, referring to Mr. LaBute's more recent forays into romantic comedy ("Nurse Betty") and period romance ("Possession"). "I believe that about him and I also believe that about myself. I have my many sides, and I like running around and taking it easy and having some fun, and exploring the dark side as well. I'm not committing to one genre for my future at all."
In "The Core," Mr. Eckhart plays Josh Keyes, a geophysicistdrafted into leading an expedition to the center of the earth. The planet's central core has stopped spinning, and it is up to Mr. Eckhart's character, ably assisted by Hilary Swank, Delroy Lindo and Stanley Tucci, to get it moving again.
Mr. Eckhart said there was no difference between the way he prepares for a Neil LaBute movie and what he did on "The Core." "This may be a popcorn movie, but for me, I try to give it my all," he said. "Sometimes I do a good job and sometimes I don't, but I put a lot of work into everything I do, or else it's meaningless to me and I have no business doing it."

Political Idealists
"Stevie," a troubling first-person documentary about the filmmaker Steve James's relationship with a deeply troubled young man whom Mr. James worked with in a Big Brother program, opens today in New York (review, Page 28). It's a challenging, unconventional film that poses more questions -- about the documentarian's relationship to his subject, about the limitations of the cinema as an instrument of truth -- than it presumes to answer.
That's the quality that makes it a Kartemquin film, the latest in a long line of politically engaged documentaries ("Hoop Dreams" is the most famous) produced by the Chicago-based Kartemquin company, founded in 1966 by a group of University of Chicago students.
Though its organizational basis has evolved, Kartemquin has never wavered from its political ideals, said Gordon Quinn, one of the three founders. What began as a collective in the 1960's, creating fiercely political work, turned into a full-scale production company in the 70's, when the political work was subsidized by industrial films and sports shows made for television.
"We kept it going, and it evolved over the years into its new form," Mr. Quinn said by phone from the company's Chicago offices, "where we had a group of producers with us making films largely for television broadcast -- films that we thought could get people emotionally connected, by getting people involved with a story and human lives, to draw them in so that they would see things from another perspective. Then, the underlying social and political and economic issues would be something that the audience would care about. As we became older, we returned to something that we were very interested in at our beginnings."
Kartemquin now receives much of its financing from organizations like the MacArthur Foundation and the Public Broadcasting System. For PBS, Kartemquin is producing a seven-part series called "New Americans," scheduled for this fall. It will follow several immigrant families over a period of several years as they leave their home countries and try to adapt to life in the United States.
"It's very important for us to stick with the story and stay with it for as long as it takes," Mr. Quinn said. "And sometimes that's a difficult thing to explain to a funder, when you're seven years down the line. We really feel that one of the things that's needed in America's debate about social issues is a sense of human complexity."

HEADLINE: South Korea's New Leader Offers Plan to Spur Investment 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, March 27 

 BODY:
The new administration of President Roh Moo Hyun announced sweeping economic proposals today meant to attract investment into fields ranging from golf courses to factories to car dealerships, as concerns grow that South Korea's economy may be sliding toward another crisis like the one that flattened it in 1997. 
 With economic growth slowing, President Roh's team of financial advisers concluded that waiting any longer to act would endanger the economy, and they won approval from the cabinet for broad deregulation. 
 "We have pursued this program for a long time," said Bahk Byong Won, director general for economic policy at the Finance Ministry. "The present economic difficulty has persuaded the ministers of the need to put it into action." 
Mr. Roh's administration took up the program after first pursuing and then quickly backing away from another initiative that Mr. Roh and his supporters had advocated through the election campaign, a crackdown on the excesses of the chaebol, the giant family-run conglomerates that have dominated the South Korean economy for decades. 
Mr. Roh and his advisers, some of them viewed as liberal reformers who would like to reduce the power of the chaebol over the economy, were persuaded to reverse course because of concerns about the economic effect of a scandal at one of the largest chaebol, the SK Group.
Ten executives of the group were indicted this month after SK Global, the group's trading arm, was found to have understated its debt and overstated its earnings for 2001; two of the executives are being held by police. The prosecutions at SK and the new government's anti-chaebol talk touched off a wave of withdrawals from investment funds and sent stock and bond markets reeling.
One aim of the new proposals is to remove obstacles to investment in new factories. Economic planners believe the economy needs this kind of investment to sustain growth at a time when oil prices are high. 
The new rules would, among other things, clear the way for construction of the world's largest liquid-crystal display factory by Royal Philips Electronics and a semiconductor plant by Dongbu Electronics. The proposed rules would also almost double the amount of land available for building golf courses.
"We have a lot of regulations" standing in the way of development, Mr. Bahk said. "This time we are going to deregulate to make such investments possible."
Among the government's major proposals for the financial sector is a plan to set up a public corporation that would buy home mortgages from lenders, modeled on Fannie Mae in the United States. And a single holding company would be established to control Korea's three securities exchanges.
Pyeon Yang Ho, director general for financial policy at the finance ministry, said the general aim was to streamline financial transactions for everyone from homeowners to institutional investors.
Though the new proposals do not refer specifically to foreign investment, Mr. Pyeon said he believed that they would encourage potential investors to look at South Korean assets. Finance officials hope for more deals like the one struck today for the sale of two of the Hyundai Group's asset management businesses to Prudential Financial of the United States for $400 million.
The deal took more than a year to negotiate. The government, which brokered the deal, appeared determined to bring it to a happy ending after the shock two years ago of having the American International Group back out of a deal for control of two businesses and a third sibling.
Many of the regulations the government wants to drop are environmental rules that it says have stymied development. The government also said it would allow diesel-powered cars in the country beginning in 2005, provided that they met European emission standards, which are less strict than South Korea's.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 3556 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Millenniums of Asia, Packed Into a Week

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
One Tuesday earlier this month, some of the Metropolitan Museum's Asian art galleries had an unusual number of visitors. That day more than 300 people went to the Ancient Near Eastern galleries, and most of them did the same thing when they got there. They took out a sketchbook and pencil and silently began to make drawings of the objects around them.
 An art class field trip? No, this was a draw-in organized by a New York-based group called Artists Against the War. The galleries they chose were those with work from ancient Mesopotamia, the land that is now Iraq. 
 Their purpose, they said, was to call attention to the civilizations that had flourished there under various names -- Sumer, Babylonia, Assyria, the Arab-Muslim Abbasid empire -- during 5,000 years, and into the present. 
The objects the visitors drew included exquisite luxury items and fierce religious emblems, the latter often designed not to embody evil but to frighten it away. In certain pieces, influences from Arabia, Persia, China, India and the Mediterranean world mingled.
Whatever the specific political message of the event, by copying these Asian images over and over again, the artists seemed intent on emblazoning them on the collective consciousness of another culture, our own.
This week thousands of Asian objects have landed in Manhattan as part of the annual spring Asia Week. The International Asian Art Fair opens today; exhibitions are on at museums; dozens of galleries have cooked up special shows. (Shows of classical Chinese furniture, Antiques column, Page 44.) And the war that was threatening in early March is in progress. Inevitably, this political reality inflects the mood of the week itself, which is, after all, a market-dependent affair.
At the same time, as the collections at the Met suggest, it is a prism through which art itself can be viewed with fresh eyes, as a powerful but fragile carrier of social and spiritual information, aspirations and fears.

Art Fairs
The International Asian Art Fair is back at the Seventh Regiment Armory after last year's post-9/11 adventure in a tent in a West Side park. The show's 2003 edition -- its seventh -- looks very much at home again, but also different, at once denser and thinner.
The number of galleries participating has grown, to 55 from last year's 49. But the spectacular, big-ticket objects that used to give this fair a distinctive grandeur are few and far between. Although there is plenty of everything, most of that plenty seems smaller. This may be a reflection of political and economic jitters, or the diminishing availability of material, or the fact that certain charismatic galleries that have dropped out of the fair over time have been replaced by less distinguished newcomers. Whatever, that's where we are.
That said, where we are is still at the top of the art fair heap in New York. I judge this by applying two criteria: one, does a fair offer objects the likes of which you have never seen before, and, two, does it have art of a kind you passionately love but almost never see available elsewhere? The answer has always been yes and yes for the Asian Art Fair and still is.
One item that I would place in the first category is an 11th-century stone finial from a stupa, or Buddhist reliquary monument, at John Eskenazi's booth, with carved figures ranged in tiers from top to bottom on all four sides. That it survived intact, considering the height from which it presumably descended, is miraclous.
Another is the sandstone base for what must have been an immense carved Dharmachakra, or Wheel of the Buddhist Law, seen at the booth shared by Doris and Nancy Wiener. This majestic sculpture with its sinuous patterns symbolizing the core ingredients of the religion itself -- the Buddha, the Dharma and the monastic community, or Sangha -- probably dates from the first century B.C. or A.D. Although such objects are often depicted in relief carvings, I have never seen one of this size "live."
And as for passionately loved things too seldom encountered, the London dealer Sam Fogg has this year again brought a significant cache of non-Indian Islamic art. It includes examples of calligraphy in the form of Koran pages from ninth- and 10th-century Iraq. No text in the world is more hypnotic when spoken aloud than the Koran, and none more beautiful when written out by hand. In addition, Mr. Fogg has a display of early bowls with calligraphic inscriptions: "he is he" (meaning "God is God"), says one; "greed is a sign of poverty," says another; "good food," says a third.
Finally, among this year's newcomers, M. Sutherland Fine Arts from New York is showing contemporary Asian painting, treading a path forged at the fair by Michael Goedhuis, who has up-to-date material at his booth and at his gallery on East 76th Street, and by China 2000, which has both 20th-century traditional painting by Shao Yixuan(1886-1954) and fascinating political work from the revolutionary era, with upbeat depictions of what was for many a period of catastrophic human folly. The social historians and the art historians alike will find much to ponder here.
At the 69th Regiment Armory, the Arts of Pacific Asia Show is a natural destination for anyone who is in the market for something "Asian," but reluctant to spend huge sums. More than 80 dealers, from cities as far flung as Amsterdam and Ann Arbor, have been shoehorned into the armory.
Certain galleries -- Cynthia Shaver with Japanese textiles, for example, and Marc Richards with Chinese sculpture -- make an elegant thing of their closet-size space. Most booths have the chockablock visual busyness that looks like home-away-from-home to the obsessive, which is not to say undiscriminating, collector.

Museums
In contrast to international politics, Asian art fairs are, in their modest way, triumphs of diplomacy. They bring diverse people from around the globe together through shared self-interest, in this case to buy and sell art. And the art itself is often -- almost always, in fact -- a product of a complex process of cultural give and take.
This kind of exchange is boldly proposed and entertainingly examined in "Great Waves: Chinese Themes in the Arts of Korea and Japan" at the Met. Basically the show is a collection reinstallation done with a novel mix-and-match approach. Spread over both the Chinese painting galleries and the Japanese galleries, it traces the flow of influence from one culture to the other. Most of the action takes place in the Chinese galleries, where the art is arranged by pictorial motifs -- seascapes, landscapes, floral images -- that emerged early in China and later circulated to Korea and Japan. In modern times the direction of the flow reversed itself when 19th- and early 20th-century Chinese painters in Shanghai began taking their stylistic cues from Japanese art.
The show's thesis is sure to provide grist for many scholarly mills, which is what exhibitions should do. Organized by Maxwell K. Hearn and Miyeko Murase, both of the museum's Asian art department, it is tremendous fun to look at: What? This beside this? Who would have thought?
If it has a major fault it is that Korea, underrepresented in the Met collection, is also underrepresented in the show's historical scheme. The imbalance will be at least partly rectified in another show, "Transmitting the Forms of Divinity: Early Buddhist Art From Korea and Japan," to open at the Japan Society on April 9. The small Korean gilt Buddha that sold for more than $1.5 million earlier this week at Christie's New York further whets the appetite for what we will see there.
Indeed, if any force can be said to unite East Asian cultures, it would be Buddhism. And as if in direct response to uneasy times, the pacific images associated with this religion are to be found everywhere during Asia Week. Nowhere are they more concentrated than in "The World of Buddhism: Selections From the Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3rd Collection" at the Asia Society and Museum. Anyone familiar with the collection is already feeling blissed out by its return to public view. Everyone else will have the delight of a first-time encounter with its embodiment of the Buddha in many forms, from an earthly figure carved from stone in fifth-century India, to the celestial eighth-century bronze Buddha of the Future, probably made in northern Thailand and now one of the great art sights of New York.
The Asia Society has set aside a gallery as a "meditation room" for the occasion. With low lighting, scrolls on the walls and a carpeted floor, it's a nice place to power down from what seems these day like an all-news-all-the-time city. The show itself is a component of the "Buddhism Project," a series of exhibitions being mounted by several New York institutions over the next year. The next segment is a contemporary art show, "The Commodification of Buddhism," to open at the Bronx Museum of the Arts on Thursday.

Tibetan Art
When the International Asian Art Fair began in 1996, it was accompanied by a few short-run exhibitions by local galleries or out-of-town dealers in rented spaces. Seven years later there are dozens of such shows, large and small, turning what was once a fairly leisurely round of visits into an aesthetic marathon.
Among the most rewarding special exhibitions this year are two showcases of Buddhist art from the Himalayas. "Images of Devotion From the Himalayas and South Asia," by the London gallery Rossi & Rossi is not large, but it is stunning, and if I had to choose just one place to hang out for a while, it would be the front gallery of this show.
At its center are a pair of sweet-faced copper deer that might once have surmounted a monastery gateway. Flanking them are two ravishing paintings from central Tibet, one of the Buddha preaching to a throng of lamas and saints, the other of a spiritual being named the Goddess of the Glorious White Parasol, who has a danger-repelling face and multicolored heads stacked up in a beehive. Most interesting of all is a diagrammatic drawing of the cosmos, showing heaven, earth and the mysterious land of Shambala, an Eden accessible only to the pure of heart. Oddly enough, in this version it seems to coincide with earth.
These objects, like much Tibetan art that has arrived in the West since the Chinese occupation, are political refugees. So are many of the amazing sculptures in "Faces of Tibet: The Wesley and Carolyn Halpert Collection" at Carlton Rochell. Mr. Rochell, formerly head of the department of South Asian art at Sotheby's, opened his own gallery last fall, and his first Asia Week show is a beauty. Most of the sculptures are from a well-known American private collection -- collection shows abound this year -- and take the form of what might be called spiritual portraits.
They include a rogue's gallery of wild-and-crazy holy men known as mahasiddhas, as well as a group of characterful lamas. Scrawny or paunchy, smiling or dour, no two looking remotely alike. By contrast, a painted portrait of the monastic abbot Sangye Yarjon (1203-1272) is a model of formal decorum, serene and superb.

Japanese Art
"Shinto" at Koichi Yanagi, minute and ineffably lovely, was my favorite Asia Week exhibition last year. The Yanagi show this spring, "Buddha," is not quite in that rarefied class but is still a must-see if only for a single object: a small eighth-century bronze sculpture of Yakushi Buddha, or Healing Buddha, based on prototypes developed in Korea. Originally gilded, this figure seems to have at some point been scorched in a fire, and its survival from destruction lends it an extra measure of sanctity.
A far more modest Japanese Buddha can be found at Suzanne Mitchell Asian Fine Arts, which has opened its by-appointment-only doors for an Asia Week show. In this case the figure is a bodhisattva drawn on a slip of paper, colored with soft rainbow hues and mounted on a scroll. The image dates from the Late Heian period (circa 900 to 1185), but the stylistic leap to 21st-century manga work is not so great.
If you look closely, you can even turn up a Buddhist reference -- a nun with a shaved head, for example -- in the determinedly secular contents of "Masterpieces of Ukiyo-e: Paintings from the Manno Art Museum," an exhibition put together by Sebastian Izzard in association with the London Gallery of Tokyo. The pictures are, almost without exception, of the fleshly paradise known as the Yoshiwara, the classy red-light district of Edo, now Toyko. This pleasure quarter is most familiar as the subject of woodblock prints, but it also inspired paintings of enormous wit and considerable beauty.
A handscroll by Hishikawa Moronobu (circa 1618-1694) serves as an illustrated guide to the district. Although only a section of it is is on view, it is packed with picaresque details, from cooks preparing meals in the brothel kitchen, to women and their clients napping and playing games in an adjoining room, surrounded by such upscale accouterments as landscape screens painted in the fashionable Chinese style.

Chinese Art
Luxury items for the living and for for the dead account for the entries in "Chinese Works of Art From the Stoclet Collection," a characteristically dazzling Asia Week contribution from the London dealer Giuseppe Eskenazi. The 18 pieces come from the vast pan-cultural array of art amassed by the Belgian financier Adolphe Stoclet (1871-1949). Mr. Eskenazi has shown Chinese pieces from the collection since the 1970's, but obviously the source has yet to run dry. This year's selection ranges from a bronze and silver inlaid bracket in the form of mythical beasts, from the Late Eastern Zhou (fourth to third century B.C.), to a fantastic beaked chimera, or bixie, from the Han dynasty (202 B.C. to A.D. 220), to a seventh-century limestone bodhisattva's head with an elaborate carved crown and a sublime smile.
Exhibitions at J. J. Lally & Company Oriental Art, across 57th Street in the Fuller Building, are something to look forward to throughout the year and "Bronze and Gold in Ancient China" this spring is no exception. It opens with a group of gilt bronze plaques, one in the form of a vivacious phoenix. And this image, like almost everything on view -- including a bronze lamp in the form of a gold-robed sentry and a set of extraordinary carved narrative titles -- was created to amuse, instruct or protect the dead, in a culture as fixated on the afterlife as our own is entangled in the minutiae of the here and now.
Funerary goods also dominate the extravagant display of Chinese work brought by Gisele Croes from Belgium. Ms. Croes exhibited at the Asian Fair until last year and her booth, always at the very center of the armory and filled with ancient bronzes, was legendary. Her material this year is as entrancing as always, but piece by piece smaller in size and more varied, leavening monumental Shang vessels with, for example, an exquisite silver and gold Buddhist reliquary, its interior incised with lotuses and dragons, from the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618 to 907) and Tang tomb frescoes of court figures, including a woman with jet-black hair, bee-stung lips and and a daringly low-cut gown.
Finally, for a sense of the kinds of luxury fabrics from which such dresses were probably made, you can do no better than visit "Weaving China's Past: The Amy S. Clague Collection of Chinese Textiles" at China Institute Gallery. The gallery has a sterling record for presenting fine-tuned scholarly shows; this one, imported from the Phoenix Art Museum, exactly fits this description, with examples of silk brocades, tapestries and embroideries, including Buddhist ritual pieces dating from the Jin to the Qing dynasty (1644-1911).
It is ideally, if serendipitously, complemented by a second show, "Luxurious Essentials" at Kaikodo, composed primarily of painted fans, representing a minor but flourishing medium in Chinese art. Such respected Ming and Qing period artists as Qiu Ying, Tang Yin, Wen Zhengming, Yun Shouping and Wang Yuanqi are all represented in a show presenting relatively affordable and highly portable art.

Contemporary Art
Alongside this week's wealth of traditional Asian art, there is an entire parallel universe of contemporary work, either from Asia or by Asian or Asian-American artists. Suffice it to say that such exhibitions and the numbers of galleries regularly presenting them have grown exponentially in the last decade or so, though not always smoothly.
The wave of new art from China, which seemed so strong after the Asia Society's "Inside Out" exhibition, has lost some of its initial momentum in New York, in part because the work was so plentiful and diffuse that no one has been able to shape a coherent presentation of it. Of galleries specializing in new Chinese work, Ethan Cohen Fine Arts in TriBeCa has, with hits and misses, presented it most persuasively, often in group shows like the current "Peace and Line," which includes an installation of calligraphy by the venerable painter C. C. Wang, now 97, on the pages of New York City telephone books; calligraphic paintings from 1986 by Gu Wenda; and experimental work by three young Chinese artists, Pan Xinglei, Xing Fei and Zhou Hongxiang.
New art from South Asia, meanwhile, has been consistently well represented by two galleries, both with strong shows at the moment. The artist who uses the single name Navjot is at Talwar with an installation of figures of nude women and men carved from teakwood and painted a deep, rich blue. Inspired by both religious icons and tribal art, her tableau suggests the social and sexual tensions at work in a country where women are still subject to indiscriminate abuse
At Bose Pacia Modern in Chelsea, Talha Rathore, a Pakistan-born artist living in New York, has a series of paintings done soon after 9/11 and in an atmosphere of incipient anti-Muslim sentiment. Using images from traditional Rajput painting but executed on New York City subway maps, Ms. Rathore explores what it is likely to be a Muslim visitor navigating an American culture in which she is suddenly, and irrationally, the enemy.
In the process, she raises issues about the interaction of art, life and politics that are similar to those brought out by the artists drawing together in the Met's Near Eastern galleries this month, which are also found embedded in the history of much of the work that makes up Asia Week in New York.

HEADLINE: Fourth-Quarter Output Declined to a 1.4% Pace 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
The economy slowed toward the end of last year, the Commerce Department said today.
 The gross domestic product rose in the fourth quarter at an annual rate of 1.4 percent after increasing 4 percent in the third quarter, the department said in its final snapshot of fourth-quarter growth. 
For the year, the economy grew 2.4 percent. 
The modest fourth-quarter reading on the gross domestic product -- the value of all goods and services produced in the United States -- was unchanged from a preliminary report released a month ago.
"We sort of stand on the edge of recession," Jan Hatzius, a Goldman, Sachs economist, said, adding that some sort of shock could send the economy into a slump.
Consumer spending rose at a 1.7 percent pace in the final three months of 2002, down from the 4.2 percent gain in the third quarter, reflecting a big drop in auto sales.
In addition, exports plunged and imports rose. The widening trade gap shaved 1.59 percentage points from G.D.P. growth.
Still, there were bright spots.Business investment spending increased 2.3 percent, its first gain since the third quarter of 2000, with spending on equipment and software up for a third consecutive quarter.
A solid revival in capital expenditures is considered crucial for any broad-based recovery.
The Commerce Department said after-tax corporate profits rose 4.1 percent in the quarter, the largest gain since the final quarter of 1999.
A separate report from the Labor Department said first-time claims for jobless benefits fell to 402,000 last week from a revised 427,000 the week before. Wall Street economists had expected claims at a higher level, but they said that a figure over 400,000 was not much to celebrate.
The number of workers remaining on the benefit rolls inched lower.

HEADLINE: HealthSouth Inquiry Expands to Medicare 

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 27 

 BODY:
Federal officials are investigating whether executives at HealthSouth used the illegal accounting scheme that has rocked the company as a means of cheating Medicare out of tens of millions of dollars or more, people involved in the case said today.
 The investigation of possible manipulation of Medicare reimbursements is a new front in the inquiry into the accounting scandal at HealthSouth, which was set in motion last week when a company executive admitted to participating for years in the scheme with HealthSouth's top officers. Ultimately, it has the potential of transforming the case from a fairly routine accounting scandal into an unparalleled fraud, with bogus revenue leading to the creation of fake assets that were then transformed into additional revenue. 
 The inquiry, which is preliminary, could raise doubts about the true financial performance of HealthSouth's hospitals and health care facilities, which would have filed the documents seeking reimbursement from Medicare. The value of those facilities is certain to play a significant role in the resolution of the financial crisis at HealthSouth, the nation's largest operator of rehabilitation hospitals. 
The possible interplay between the accounting scheme and a Medicare fraud is a result of rules that govern reimbursements from federal health care programs. Indeed, people involved in the case said, the accounting fraud was structured in a way that would have potentially allowed HealthSouth to obtain a significant reimbursement benefit from the scheme.
According to court documents, HealthSouth falsified revenue items involving payments it receives from insurers. Afterward, it created a corresponding entry on its balance sheets, mostly by adding to its accounts for property, plants and equipment. Some of those additions were then allocated to company hospitals and other health care facilities, according to court records and people involved in the case.
Investigators are looking into whether the hospitals and health care facilities then filed for reimbursement from Medicare for expenses associated with the suspect plant and equipment assets and other questionable accounting entries. In effect, the hospitals and health care facilities may have converted suspect assets into increased Medicare reimbursements -- unless they specifically removed the expenses associated with the assets from their filings with the government.
Peter Ashkenaz, a spokesman for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, referred questions about HealthSouth to the Justice Department, which did not comment. Ernie Knewitz, a spokesman for HealthSouth, declined to comment.
People involved in the case said the investigation of the potential Medicare reimbursement scheme remained secondary to the larger accounting fraud case, which is being handled by the United States attorney's office in Birmingham with assistance from the Justice Department's fraud division. The Atlanta office of the Securities and Exchange Commission is also participating in that inquiry.
Prosecutors in the accounting case have already obtained guilty pleas from two former senior officers of HealthSouth, who admitted to participating in the accounting conspiracy. They are Weston L. Smith, a former chief financial officer, and William T. Owens, who served in the same job until today. In their pleas, both men said that they participated in the accounting conspiracy with the company's chief executive, Richard M. Scrushy, as well as other executives, including members of the company's accounting staff. Mr. Scrushy has not been charged in the case, but he has been placed on administrative leave by the company.
As a result of his guilty plea Wednesday, Mr. Owens, who had been on administrative leave, was dismissed. However, today he continued to serve as a director; under the rules governing corporate boards, Mr. Owens can only be removed from the board if he resigns or is voted out by shareholders.
The inquiry into HealthSouth's reimbursements from Medicare is not the first time the company has been investigated for potential abuses of the federal health care program. Last May, the Justice Department joined in a suit brought by a corporate whistle-blower contending that HealthSouth improperly billed the government for providing one-on-one treatment to patients by licensed physical therapists. The suit said the patients were instead often treated in large groups, often by unlicensed individuals. 
The area under examination in the new inquiry is part of what was once an obscure part of the federal health care system known as the cost-reporting system. At the foundation of the systemis the concept that health care facilities face costs for treating Medicare patients, like building hospital rooms, that otherwise might not have been incurred and that are not paid for through reimbursement for treatment. As a result, the government reimburses health care concerns for part of the costs of those facilities, based on the proportion of use by Medicare patients.
This cost-reporting system became the centerpiece of an investigation in the late 1990's, when federal officials discovered what they said was sweeping fraud at the company then known as the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the largest hospital operator in the country. The government accused Columbia/HCA of fraudulently misrepresenting hospital-based expenses to transform nonreimbursable costs into reimbursable ones, or to identify expenses that were paid at a low rate as costs that were reimbursed at higher rates under Medicare.
Some local Columbia/HCA hospital operators were ultimately convicted of fraud, although their case was thrown out on appeal.
Last year, the company, now known as HCA, settled the civil case related to the cost-reporting allegations, agreeing to pay $880 million in fines and penalties.
The circumstances surrounding the HealthSouth inquiry differ substantially from those at Columbia. Columbia involved expenses that were actually incurred but improperly identified. At HealthSouth, the government is trying to determine whether artificial expenses were created and run through the system.
Moreover, the Columbia case often involved actions by local hospital administrators; in the case of HealthSouth, because the accounting fraud was directed from some of the highest reaches of the company, local hospitals would have little way of knowing whether they were submitting claims for false expenses.
According to documents filed in the accounting case, the HealthSouth accounting fraud largely involved manipulation of what is known as contractual adjustment -- the difference between gross charges to patients and the amount that a company expects to be reimbursed by insurers. Accounting principles generally require any increase in revenue or reduction in expenses to be matched with an increase in assets or a reduction in liabilities. As a result, the manipulation of the contractual adjustments resulted in huge -- and artificial -- increases in the company's assets, according to court documents.
Those adjustments most frequently found their way into what is known as the property, plant and equipment account -- an asset account that is known among cost-reporting experts as something of a financial honey pot. As of the second quarter of 2002, of the $1.5 billion in artificial assets listed on the company's balance sheet as a result of the accounting fraud, at least $1 billion of them found their way into the property, plant and equipment account, according to court documents.
Participants in the scheme allocated certain portions of the bogus assets to hospitals and health care facilities, often in a manner intended to avoid raising suspicions among the company's accountants, the court filings said. Such assets in turn could generate related noncash expenses, like depreciation.
Ultimately, unless hospital administrators specifically removed the costs from their filings with the government, those expenses would filter through to Medicare, which in turn would pay its proportional share of such costs at a predetermined rate. Medicare accounted for just under a third of the company's revenue, according to company filings.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The HealthSouth Medical Center in Birmingham, Ala. A federal inquiry into accounting fraud at HealthSouth is now said to include suspected improprieties involving federal Medicare reimbursements. (Steve Gates for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: An Uprising in Albany, Almost 

 BODY:
Albany's Bermuda Triangle -- those three-man huddles where the democratic process disappears behind closed doors -- briefly lost a leg this week as Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, came up with a way to fix the state's cash crisis without first getting the governor on board. It was a welcome display of action that contrasted sharply with Gov. George Pataki's determined disengagement from reality in addressing the state's $11.5 billion budget shortfall. 
 The governor has been at odds with legislators of both parties since he made his budget proposal, which slashed $1.2 billion from education, foisting on localities the burden of keeping schools running, and cut $1 billion in the growth of Medicaid, threatening the financial health of hospitals in the state. Governor Pataki ruled out any "job-killing taxes," but he appeared to be daring the legislators to reinstate some of the spending and take the heat for tax increases needed to pay the bill. The only thing all parties agree on is that, as in past years, the April 1 budget deadline will not be met. 
 But legislators have a more immediate dilemma: a gap in the current year's budget and the very real possibility that the state could run out of cash next week without an infusion of money. Mr. Bruno, a Republican, and Mr. Silver, a Democrat, are as much natural allies as a cobra and a mongoose. But with Mr. Pataki focused elsewhere, they produced a compromise that would have the state borrow $4.2 billion, $700 million immediately, against money expected from New York's share of the tobacco suit settlement. Mr. Silver initially opposed tapping the tobacco funds, which have been targeted to help finance health care, but relented after it was agreed that the borrowing would be guaranteed by personal income tax revenues. That compromise would protect funds for health care while offering cheaper debt servicing for the state. Further, none of the tobacco money will be available until a final budget is passed, something that would seem to ensure some attention from the governor.
Mr. Pataki has made it clear that at the top of his agenda these days -- apparently to the detriment of other matters, including budgetary -- is supporting the war effort and helping to prevent terrorism in the state. While guarding New Yorkers' safety is urgently important, so is solving a financial crisis with crushing, long-term implications. The governor needs to be part of the solution.

HEADLINE: Back to Work, And to Family, At Ground Zero; 
Hotel Employees Reunite After 9/11 and Joblessness

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Outside the Millenium Hilton Hotel, Kofi Myantakyi was resplendent in his green doorman's blazer with the black trim and gold buttons as he helped a guest into a cab. Then a woman yelled, "Look at the plane!" 
 Mr. Myantakyi looked across Church Street at the World Trade Center, and there was the jet. "It was blue and white," he recalled, "and I stared with disbelief as it moved right into that building. I saw the smoke. I thought, 'Just like 1993.' And then came the sirens. And that, too, was just like 1993." 
 It seemed to be Mr. Myantakyi's fate to be on duty whenever terrorists attacked the twin towers. 
The hotel has been closed for 18 months. In that time, Mr. Myantakyi, 42, and many other Millenium veterans have not been able to find work. 
But at last, he and most of the 360 former employees are coming back to the nearly reconstructed hotel, which is on track for a May 5 ribbon cutting. 
"I'm not sure how I'll feel, to be outside in the same place," Mr. Myantakyi said on a recent afternoon at the hotel, "to be rehashing everything again and again. I get very emotional about it. There is no way I can tell how I'll feel till I'm out there in uniform again."
About 150 of the employees were on duty on Sept. 11, 2001, and the hotel had about 650 guests. Thanks to a quick evacuation, not a single guest or hotel worker was lost inside the Millenium. But 12 guests who went across the street to the twin towers never returned. 
Most of the hotel employees have been out of work ever since the attack, because of the economic downturn. About 90 percent of them have agreed to come back.
"I just can't wait until everyone is here," said Leonard Williams, 55, who did cleaning and maintenance work. "We old-timers are calling it our second opening," he said, because -- like Mr. Myantakyi -- he was on hand when the hotel opened on June 10, 1992. "But this will be more emotional than the first one." 
The Millenium -- at 58 stories, one of New York's tallest hotels -- is owned by City Developments Limited and managed by the Hilton Hotels Corporation. It stretches along Church Street from Fulton Street south to Dey Street.
Unlike the Marriott World Trade Center Hotel, to the west of the south tower, the Millenium survived the terrorist attacks. Although the hotel did not suffer major structural damage, two-thirds of its glass front was broken or damaged beyond repair. 
Roger Swadish, a Boston-based Hilton operations vice president who acted as the managing director of the Millenium after that day, went back inside it two days after the towers fell. "I was in shock at first," he said, "to see the fire, the smoke, the damage to the hotel." 
Because of the toxic contaminants from the disaster, "we had to take the entire hotel down to the drywall," Mr. Swadish said. 
The reconstruction cost $31 million, according to Mr. Swadish. Returning guests will be comforted by the same -- now sanitized -- Brazilian lacquered rosewood in the lobby, and 565 rooms that have been rebuilt and redecorated. 
For the reunited employees, it has been a time of reconnection and recollection. "So many of us bonded in 1992, when we opened the hotel," said Beverly Tomlinson, 54, a cleaning attendant. "Then we all shared the attack in 1993. So many people came out of the smoke into our lobby -- they were frightened and crying. I'll never forget the sooty faces. After that experience, the staff was one big family." 
So, for many of the workers, the 2001 attack seemed at first to be a replay.
"The lights flickered in 2001 just like they did when the bomb went off in 1993," Mr. Williams said. "I had a flashback."
Eric Brown, 32, a house runner who brought guests towels and toiletries, said that when he saw the trade center on fire, "my first reaction was to run over to the buildings and help somebody." But, he said, "the police kept people away." 
Upstairs, in the third-floor restaurant, the morning manager, Ly Tien, 25, "saw the debris coming down like confetti."
"I realized that it was time for an evacuation," she said. She guided the guests out, helped by the chef and the room service manager.
Meanwhile, Ms. Tomlinson said, 50 room attendants were up on the hotel floors.
"Some guests thought they wanted to stay, so the ladies and security had to coax them to come down," she said. That probably saved lives when the towers collapsed and the hotel's glass facade imploded. 
One of the guests was a pilot who left his hand-held aviation radio in his hotel room. Initially, another guest, an Egyptian student, was suspected of owning the radio and using it to communicate with the terrorists, but all charges against him were dropped. He subsequently sued the hotel in a case that is pending.
Down in the lobby, Ray Burgos, 37, now the human resources manager at the hotel, tried "to persuade people not to go outside, where they might be injured," he said. Early on, he commandeered a cart of clean laundry and began handing out towels to the dazed, dirty and sometimes bloody trade center survivors. 
Many of them needed water. "But we didn't have enough water pitchers," Mr. Burgos said, "so we dumped liquor out of the bottles in the lobby bar, filled them with water and gave them to people in need. One guy said: 'What kind of water is this? It tastes like Scotch!' " He drank it anyway. 
The hotel staff was spared none of the horrors of the day.
"When I saw the people jumping, I was praying to God," Mr. Williams said. "And then they began hitting the wooden concert platform in the plaza, where I used to see the concerts they had. It was horrible. I cried like a baby." 
After the towers collapsed, the uniformed hotel employees made their way home as best they could. "All our credit cards, ID's and house keys were in our lockers," Mr. Brown said. "I had my I.R.S. refund check for $300 in my locker. I was going to cash it that day. Instead, it was stuck in my locker for months." 
Only 60 of the employees were able to find jobs in other Hilton hotels, because tourism had dropped off and the chain was cutting back. 
Ms. Tien found work as the manager of a vegetarian restaurant. When that job ended, she realized that she felt "out of it," she recalled. "I was freaking out because of the memories -- the bleeding and helpless people that I could not help."
Spontaneously, she took a trip to Hawaii, "and when I got back I was O.K." 
Mr. Williams looked for work unsuccessfully for five months, and then he ran out of unemployment benefits in July. "I thank God for my wife and my son for getting me through this," he said. 
All the employees kept their health benefits because labor and management agreed to alternate in paying the cost, month by month. So far this has cost the company more than $1 million. But Mr. Swadish, the Hilton operations vice president, said, "We wanted our core team back." 
The gesture has also tapped the resources of the New York Hotel Trades Council, the umbrella organization of unions that represents about 25,000 workers. According to Peter Ward, the council's president, since the trade center attack it has spent $2 million, because it also helped cover the medical benefit expenses of 400 surviving workers from the Marriott World Trade Center and 100 from the nearby Embassy Suites Hotel, which has reopened. 
On its last day of operation, the Millenium's average room rate was $325 a night. When it reopens, its rooms will average about $200 a night for the first months, "since we know that a lot of our old customers have gone to our competition, and we'd like to get them back," Mr. Swadish said. 
Although many of the rooms will offer a spectacular view of ground-zero reconstruction, Mr. Swadish said the hotel's new advertising would not mention this. 
"We have a great sensitivity about looking as if we're exploiting the situation," he said. "But obviously, we are very proud of having been here, and of having survived. And we are very proud to be coming back."

HEADLINE: Japan Puts Deregulation to Big Test 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 27 

 BODY:
It is the biggest test yet of the Japanese way of deregulation: "market-opening," "money-saving" measures that actually introduce only a limited amount of competition while leaving almost everything important just the way it was. So it will probably be with Japan Post, a new public corporation, that will replace the government-run Postal Services Agency on April 1.
 The post office is a much bigger actor in the economy than the U.S. Postal Service is in the United States, and it is not broken. Mail delivery is highly reliable, and the savings and insurance programs it runs -- the world's largest piggy bank -- provide a safe and popular shelter for consumers who are worried about leaving money in Japan's shaky commercial banks. 
 But with Japan's national budget deficit yawning ever wider, lawmakers are trying to turn as many bureaucracies as they can into freestanding companies with a more limited and indirect claim on the public purse, and few look riper than Japan Post.
Supporters of the new deregulated corporate structure say it will open the post office's books to more public scrutiny and to management by professional executives recruited from private industry instead of career bureaucrats. They say it will have a freer hand to cut costs and introduce new services. 
"We want to create a self-supporting system that allows us autonomy and flexibility," said Masaharu Ikuta, the president of Japan Post and former chairman of Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, a shipping company in Japan. "Of course, our workers are public servants, but we will be managed like a private company."
Other countries have cut their postal services loose from the state, with mixed results. Germany took Deutsche Post public in 2000, and while the stock has performed poorly, the company has been profitable and is expanding overseas; its Netherlands-based private courier subsidiary, DHL Worldwide Express, made an offer this week to buy Airborne. New Zealand, with a much smaller population, made its post office an autonomous but still state-owned business in the 1990's and opened mail delivery to competition, but service has deteriorated. In Britain, the loss-plagued Royal Mail Group is being reorganized.
The Postal Service in the United States also runs chronic deficits -- more than $1 billion in each of the last two fiscal years -- and the Bush administration set up a commission in December to seek ways to streamline its operations, battle rising costs and reverse the decline in letter volume.
Having seen deregulation falter overseas, Japan Post is cautious about leaving the state's nest. Like most postal agencies, it clings to its mission of providing universal service, with mailboxes nationwide and uniform domestic postal rates regardless of distance -- a policy that is popular in politically powerful districts in the countryside and that effectively excludes new entrants from the most lucrative part of the market, delivering ordinary business mail. 
Private delivery companies are instead focusing on next-day express mail and other special services, much as they do in the United States. 
Competition aside, Japan Post is looking to wring savings from a business that is notorious for inefficiencies. Experts have been called in from Toyota Motor (Toyota's chairman, Hiroshi Okuda, sits on the Japan Post board) to introduce just-in-time techniques to mail-carrying. Mr. Ikuta's team may also lengthen business hours at post offices and automated teller machines, and has already struck deals with convenience stores to sell stamps. 
Mr. Ikuta, who won praise for reviving Mitsui O.S.K., has so far sidestepped questions about how he planned to tackle the biggest cost of all, the payroll. As in the United States, Germany and elsewhere, full-time postal workers in Japan have the same civil-service protections as government employees and are extremely difficult to lay off. Japan Post, with 290,000 employees, has been trying to gain flexibility through attrition, replacing full-time workers who quit or retire with cheaper and less protected part-time employees. 
Japan Post has set goals of trimming 32 billion yen ($267 million) from labor costs over the next four years and introducing merit-based pay, moves that analysts called mild for an organization its size. Yet even these plans have rattled labor unions into opposition. 
"We feel threatened by the formation of the public corporation," said Kazuhiro Sudo, an organizer at Zenrokyo, a network of postal labor unions. "Japan Post officials are starting to use the word reform. We are worried that bosses will use the evaluation system to push workers out." 
Deregulating the post office is a more sensitive proposition than the country's two previous giant privatizations -- Nippon Telegraph and Telephone and the subdivided national railway -- because of the huge role the post office plays in the nation's finances. The system's savings and insurance programs manage 335 trillion yen ($2.8 trillion) in customers' assets, one-quarter of the country's total savings.
For decades, the post office has invested most of this money in special government bonds that financed public-works projects and a web of organizations that critics say are little more than patronage mills and sinecures for retired bureaucrats. Lawmakers from Mr. Koizumi's Liberal Democratic Party, which depends on support from rural districts, also note that the post office is the only financial institution in many small towns.
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi floated a far-reaching proposal last summer that would have split the post office into three businesses, but he backed away from the idea after a public showdown with conservative lawmakers. Instead, the government plans to relax the restrictions on how Japan Post invests, permitting the company to put some money in the hands of outside asset managers to help increase returns, a big concern with interest rates near zero. Later, Japan Post will be allowed to start including more stocks in its portfolio. 
But it will still have to keep at least three-quarters of its assets in government bonds, meaning that lawmakers will still have captive financing for the national deficit and for their pet projects, and the nation's banks and insurers will still have the post office as a competitor.
"If the government were serious about changing the post office and deregulating the savings and insurance programs, the bond market would collapse," said Akio Mikuni, who runs an independent credit agency. "So nothing will change."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE IRAQI CAPITAL; 
Iraqi Defense Chief Vows Fight, Predicting Baghdad Clash in Days

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 27 

 BODY:
Iraq's defense minister said today that American forces could encircle "great parts of Baghdad" in as little as 5 to 10 days, but that the ensuing battle could last as long as two months, perhaps longer, with paramilitary groups loyal to Saddam Hussein joining regular troops to mount a street-by-street defense of this city of five million people. 
 "For us, Baghdad will become the cemetery where the enemy will be buried," the defense minister, Gen. Sultan Hashim, said at a news conference. "God willing, we will teach the United States and the British and their allies a lesson they will never forget." 
 The warning came as American aircraft resumed their attacks on Baghdad with some of the heaviest strikes of the eight-day-old war. Sorties throughout the day were followed, around midnight, with explosions of such momentous power that the entire city shook. Car alarms were set off as far as 10 miles from the blasts, and mosques, on Saddam Hussein's orders, began their nightly ritual of amplified calls to God. 
"Allah u Akbar! Allah u Akbar!" -- "God is Great -- the muezzins cried plaintively deep into the night, in the words of the most sacred of Muslim prayers. 
After the trembling of the ground, and reverberations that ran like shivers through the concrete frame of the Palestine Hotel about a mile from the blasts across the Tigris river, the city fell silent again for 5, sometimes 10 or 15 minutes. 
Then there were more roars from the engines of cruise missiles as they streaked low across the city for 30 or 40 seconds, more blasts, and more satanic bursts of flame, followed by huge clouds of dust and smoke drifting down the river on the night wind. 
The impacts appeared to be concentrated on the west bank of the river in the city center, site of many of the buildings considered central to Mr. Hussein's power. Pentagon officials said the targets included command-and-control centers as well as telecommunications hubs.
Bombs and missiles last Friday night struck mostly totemic targets, including two of Mr. Hussein's favorite palaces, the massive blocklike building housing his presidential office, and Republican Guard quarters. 
Any certainty about which buildings were struck tonightawaited dawn, when Western reporters moving about the city under government guide would have their first opportunity to look for newly blasted structures in the heavily guarded compounds where the most secret agencies work. 
On Wednesday night, the Pentagon demonstrated a new focus when it scored a direct hit on a telecommunications building, depriving Mr. Hussein's government of landline telephone service.
The site lay immediately adjacent to the tallest building in Iraq, the 700-foot high Saddam Tower, which appeared to suffer only shattered windows at its base. The tower, with a bulblike structure at mid-level that houses a popular restaurant, became a symbol of Mr. Hussein's defiance when it was destroyed by an American missile strike in the Persian Gulf war of 1991, then rebuilt with a statue of Mr. Hussein at its base. 
The platform supporting the statue features a scattering of American missile fragments. Bronze medallions of the first President Bush and Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister, are embedded at the statue's feet. Wedding parties routinely stop at the statue, seemingly for the purpose of reaffirming the loyalty of newlyweds and their families to Mr. Hussein. 
Only days before the new war began, a Sudanese elevator operator in the tower inquired nervously of visiting Westerners whether the needlelike structure was likely to be destroyed again. But this time, Pentagon targeters succeeded in sparing the tower even as they struck the blocklike building of about 10 stories that sits perhaps 100 to 150 feet awayto the tower's side, housing a key telephone exchanges. 
At daybreak, telephones across much of the western side of the city had gone dead, and the shattered telecommunications structure was a hollowed-out shell, with great steel panels and other interior fittings petalled outward by the blast from about the sixth floor down to the ground.
One building that reported having lost its phones was Al Rashid, the most favored of the city's five-star hotels in normal times, but largely abandoned in the past week after warnings from the Pentagon that a potential target, a telecommunications node, was buried deep beneath the hotel. 
For the people of Baghdad, the intensified bombing added to mounting anxieties about what lies ahead. Only a little more than a week after the first missile strike, failed to kill Mr. Hussein and other top leaders, American troops and armor have traveled more than 200 miles across the desert from Kuwait, to forward positions between the Euphrates and the Tigris that lie as little as 50 miles from Baghdad.
On Thursday night, 1,000 more American troops parachuted onto a Kurdish-controlled airfield about 200 miles north of Baghdad, opening a northern front to draw pressure off American troops in the south.
For Mr. Hussein's government, the vise is tightening, on the ground and from the air. But the closer the might of the American ground troops approaches to Baghdad, and the more intense the city's bombing, the more Mr. Hussein and top officials profess to be ready -- eager, even -- for a climactic showdown with America. On its face, any matchup between two nations with such vastly different military and economic resources might seem, at least to all but the most zealous of Mr. Hussein's associates, like a chronicle foretold.
But the defense minister's remarks tonight, and similar pronouncements in recent days, convey a sense that Mr. Hussein and his inner circle believe that the United States has made a catastrophic mistake in underestimating Iraq's ability to strike back. 
The message from the Mr. Hashim, the defense minister, was that Iraq has been content from the start to wait for American troops to march north -- harassing American columns as they flank cities like Basra, Nasariya, Samawa, Najaf and Karbala, ambushing, capturing and killing American soldiers as opportunities arise -- until the moment when they arrive at the gates of Baghdad. 
At his news conference, General Hashim adopted the tone of a military professional as he ran through a detailed briefing on the war so far, as viewed by Iraq. As a veteran of Iraq's eight-year war with Iran in the 1980's, he is regarded by many Iraqis as a more reliable voice on the progress of the current fighting than the political elite around Mr. Hussein, who have a habit of falling quickly into the vengeful polemics about "villains" and "criminals" favored by the Iraqi leader.
For the second time in five days, General Hashim appeared in a hotel conference room, with a staff officer directing a pointer at red stickers on a large military map. By the general's account, American officers have shaded the truth, understating the severity of the challenge they have met from the Iraqis at every encounter since the first American troops moved into Iraq before dawn last Thursday. 
General Hashim went town by town, at some points even junction by junction, bridge by bridge, telling of Iraq's success in harassing the American battalions. He mocked American and British assertions that coalition troops have been in control of the port of Umm Qasr, on the Kuwait border, saying they have never advanced beyond the docks, and hold no part of the town. 
His account of the battles at Fao, Basra, Nasiriya, Samawa and Najaf were a litany of the "enemy" pushing forward, then being driven back, losing vehicles and men in virtually every major encounter.
"The enemy seems to lose trust in himself, and the whole world can see how Western leaders have deceived themselves," he said. "If you go back five or six days to look at their pronouncements before the aggression began, they were giving various predictions of a war lasting five, six, seven or perhaps eight days. Now, they are talking of a much longer war. After Umm Qasr and Fao and Nasiriya and Samawa and Najaf, you can see for yourself how those pronouncements have changed." 
The minister acknowledged Iraqi losses in the battles, and implied without giving figures that they have been heavy, especially under heavy American bombing. But he said Iraq had ample reserves of fighters, and that, in any case, American officers exaggerated the losses sustained when heavy bombers are sent to pound front-line troops.
But mainly, his argument was that Iraq has successfully exploited several advantages in the fighting, by using irregular troops who have been able to ambush the Americans and surprise them in other ways, and by its fighters' knowledge of their home terrain, and their reliance on simpler weaponry. 
He drew an analogy to an uprising among Iraqi tribesmen against British troops occupying Iraq after the collapse of the Ottoman Empire. "In the 1920 uprising, Iraqis threw out the British with very primitive weapons," he said. "And now, the level of our weapons compared with the enemy's are well known. But God willing, we, too, will throw our enemies out of Iraq." 
The crux of the war, though, he said, would be the battle for Baghdad. He conceded, in effect, that the American columns pushing north would eventually push past Iraqi units and reach Baghdad. "Our defenses are set to defend Baghdad, so we won't be surprised if in 5 or 10 days the enemy will be encircling great parts of Baghdad," he said. "Up to now, he has been able to bypass the towns along the way and go on into the desert, but in the end he will have to attack Baghdad. The important thing is, whether he reaches Baghdad today or tomorrow, he will have paid a very high price already. And our policy will remain what it has been from the start -- to minimize our own losses and inflict maximum casualties."
Once the battle lines are set outside the capital, the minister said, the American forces would be confronted by a large defensive force of Republican Guard divisions, augmented by irregular units. The struggle for the capital could continue, he said, "for 10 days, or two months, or even more," with intensive street fighting, but eventual victory would lie with the Iraqis. "As you know, Baghdad is the capital of an ancient civilization," he said. "We Iraqis inherited this history from our forefathers. Anybody who seeks to usurp this inheritance will be inviting God's wrath. So I can assure you that Baghdad will be impenetrable for the Americans and the British, for as long as any sons of the city remain alive."

HEADLINE: Coffin Maker In Syracuse Is Shut Down; 315 Jobs Lost 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, March 27 

 BODY:
After 131 years of making coffins, the Marsellus Casket Company will close over the next month, leaving 315 workers without jobs. 
 The closing, announced today by Service Corporation International, the coffin maker's troubled parent company, left workers stunned and local union and government officials angry. 
 "We feel like we've been stabbed in the back," said Bob Tompkins, representative for Service Employees International Union Local 200, which represents about 270 workers at Marsellus plants in Syracuse and nearby DeWitt. 
Though the company is guarded about the names of those buried in its coffins, those it does acknowledge include Harry S. Truman, Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy, Hubert H. Humphrey and Nelson A. Rockefeller, Vince Lombardi and Cardinal Terrence Cooke.
Workers learned of the closing on Wednesday when managers handed out paychecks a day early, canceled the second shift and told workers to attend a meeting this morning, Mr. Tompkins said. A construction crew then arrived and began boarding up the Syracuse factory. 
Syracuse's mayor, Matthew J. Driscoll, and the Onondaga County executive, Nicholas J. Pirro, met this morning with senior Service Corporation officials.
"This is completely outrageous," Mayor Driscoll said. "They never approached the state, the county or the city about how we could help." 
Stephen M. Mack, senior vice president for eastern operations of Service Corporation, which is based in Houston, said the company had conducted an analysis that showed Marsellus Casket Company could not remain competitive without its parent spending significantly to modernize the plant and develop a distribution network to replace the third-party system now being used.
"We could not justify that investment," said Mr. Mack, who declined to give cost figures but acknowledged that the parent company "did not actively pursue" help from the state or local governments. 
Mr. Mack said that Service Corporation did contact other parties about buying Marsellus Casket but found no interest. He said, however, that Service Corporation was selling Marsellus's patents, copyrights and name to Batesville Casket Company of Indiana, which is one of Marsellus's chief rivals and describes itself as the leading builder of metal and hardwood caskets. 
Mr. Mack declined to disclose the purchase price. Batesville officials did not immediately return calls seeking comment about their plans for the Marsellus name. 
The company was founded in Syracuse in 1872 by John Marsellus and became known for its handcrafted hardwood coffins. 
On the strength of second- and third-generation workers, Marsellus operated as a family-owned business until 1997, when it was acquired by Service Corporation International. Service Corporation owns more than 3,000 funeral homes, cemeteries and crematories and says it is the largest provider of funeral, cremation and cemetery services in North America. 
"We know about Marsellus's long history and tradition," Mr. Mack said. "This was an extremely difficult decision. It's just unfortunate that the business landscape in our industry has changed." 
While the number of deaths in North America has been flat, more people are choosing cremation rather than more costly burial services, Service Corporation officials say.
Service Corporation has also had fiscal and legal problems of its own. Two of its cemeteries in Florida have been accused of having bodies removed from plots and more recently deceased ones replace them. Lawsuits by family members are pending in those cases. 
Service Corporation has also reported losing $232 million in 2002 and nearly $600 million in 2001. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 29, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the closing of the 131-year-old Marsellus Casket Company in Syracuse misspelled the given name of one of the prominent people buried in the company's coffins. He was Cardinal Terence Cooke, not Terrence.
