LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
School Year of Discontent

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
THE numbers tell only part of the story. Almost half of Yonkers' 41 public schools appeared on the state list of "most improved" schools in math and English this year. In 1999, only 34 percent of its fourth graders passed the state English test. In 2002, 60 percent did. But members of the N.A.A.C.P. in Yonkers are not satisfied.
 Almost a year after a long-running federal desegregation lawsuit against the Yonkers school district was settled, the public schools, long riddled with budget deficits and high turnover rates among top administrators, have shown significant improvement, but signs of trouble linger. 
 "The results Yonkers has produced in elementary schools are very impressive," said Tom Dunn, a spokesman for the state Department of Education. "They are real gains and results of hard work." 
A different, and unequivocal, answer came from Gail Baxter, the parent coordinator for the school district and a vice president of the districtwide Parents and Teachers Association, when she was asked whether the district had changed for the better. 
"Hell, no," said Ms. Baxter, an executive board member of the Yonkers' branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the plaintiff in the desegregation suit. "Things haven't gotten worse, but my standard for better is much better than what we have." She said she would like to see the closing of achievement gaps between white and minority students. The school district has slightly more than 26,000 students, 75 percent of whom are minorities.
The suit, started in 1980 when the Yonkers branch of the N.A.A.C.P. sued the city over what it called racial segregation in housing and schools, was settled last March when the state agreed to pay $300 million to the Yonkers school district over five years for programs intended to eliminate disparities between white and minority students.
Two weeks after the settlement, the school district received the first installment of $70 million to provide extra help to failing students, to train teachers to improve their skills and to reduce suspension rates.
But difficulties soon surfaced. The district has not met a deadline for hiring a settlement compliance officer by May 1 last year. Last August it offered the job -- then withdrew its offer -- to a Hispanic lawyer, Janet Alvarez, who had held a similar post in New York City. The job was turned down by a second candidate, Tracey Collins, a former teacher in Louisiana, on Feb. 28, leaving the post still vacant 10 months after the deadline.
Joseph M. Pastore Jr., the court-appointed monitor until thesettlement was in place, said that after Ms. Collins turned down the job, he volunteered to be the host of a meeting earlier this month with representatives from the Yonkers mayor's office, the school district and the local N.A.A.C.P., with officials from the Justice Department participating on the phone. At the meeting, Mr. Pastore said he urged the school district to disclose its compliance more fully to the public. 
The resignation of the district's superintendent, Joseph L. Farmer, last Novmember upset many parents, who said he was instrumental in obtaining the settlement.
Budget woes have persisted. Despite the settlement money, the Yonkers school district had a $4.2 million gap this year. It laid off 158 teachers, guidance counselors and administrators last August. Although some were rehired, parents complained that some enrichment programs at smaller schools were eliminated because of the layoffs.
But many teachers and students said the settlement made the difference between a budget disaster and a budget squeeze. 
"The teachers became less distracted after the settlement money came," said Steve Gurusaran, a senior at Yonkers High School. "They worried less about layoffs. For us, it's hard to lose a teacher after you have grown to know him or her."
The interim superintendent, Angelo Petrone, and his team have made efforts to improve the district and comply with the settlement agreement, said many white and minority parents. One achievement was the expansion of smaller classes offered after the end of the regular school days for failing students and anyone who wants to participate.
For Abby Saleh, a sixth grader at Yonkers Middle School whose parents immigrated from Egypt, the benefits of these smaller classes are obvious. She received a 73 in the final exam of social studies two semesters ago; after she began to stay after school almost every day, she earned a 98 in the same subject. 
"The after-school program helps me to form good study habits," Abby said. 
In a recent after-school class, the teacher, Joseph Vicari, asked the children to write a review of a short documentary he had shown them. Mr. Vicari instructed the students to begin their essays with "broad or general" first sentences. When he looked for volunteers to read aloud their essays, virtually all of the 12 children raised their hands high.
But Mr. Vicari estimated that only half of the failing students stay, and often, the top students are the ones who participate in after-school programs, because participation is strictly voluntary. One student who stayed for Mr. Vacari's English class, for example, was Justina Passarelli, who received a 98 in English two semesters ago and 102 -- the highest score in the class -- last semester.
The afternoon sessions, partially financed by the settlement, however, may disappear four years from now when the settlement money dries up. Many educators and parents are concerned that the district, which can barely balance its budget now even with the settlement funds, might undergo draconian cuts.
The answer is for the state government to appropriate more schools financing to Yonkers, the state's second-largest urban center, Mr. Petrone said. Rochester, Buffalo and Syracuse, which along with New York rank in the top five, all receive far more dollars per student than Yonkers, he said.
"Why should the Yonkers taxpayers be hit with the brunt of paying for our kids' education while the other big cities are funded by the state?" asked Mr. Petrone, a former principal at Yonkers Middle School. 
Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for thestate budget office, said: "While the state faces major fiscal challenges due to 9/11 and the national recession, our schools will still benefit from overall spending levels that will place New York among the top states in the nation, and well above other major states, such as California, Texas and Florida." 
Analysis of the school district's budgets show that over the last decade, annual state aid to Yonkers schools grew by 258 percent to $233 million from $65 million, while Yonkers' own spending on education dropped by 12 percent from $130 million to $115 million. 
Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed cutting state education aid to Yonkers by 12 percent next year, and Nicholas A. Spano, the Republican representing Yonkers in the State Senate, has vowed to lobby to have at least part of the cuts restored.
But in the view of Karen Edmonson, the education chairwoman of the N.A.A.C.P. in Yonkers when it reached the settlement, the lack of financing is not the major issue. Instead, it's where the money is spent. 
"The best high schools are still on the east side" of Yonkers, she said, bristling. Minority neighborhoods are concentrated on the west side of the city. And since high school students have to take public transportation instead of school buses, some students who live on the west side of Yonkers are unwilling to go to school on the other side of the town. "They are not improving the schools on the west side," Ms. Edmonson said.

LENGTH: 1730 words

HEADLINE: Preview 03; 
Going, Going, Gone

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The statistics have a striking symmetry: before 1995, players hit 50 or more home runs in a season 18 times; in the last eight seasons, beginning with 1995, players have hit 50 or more home runs in a season 18 times.
 Either the home runs or the players, they ain't what they used to be. 
 Don't expect Barry Bonds to provide an explanation. "I've only done it once," he said, referring to hitting 50 or more home runs. Of course, the one time Bonds did it he hit 73, putting him at the forefront of the individual explosion in home runs. 
In each of the past eight seasons, at least one player has hit 50 or more home runs. In 2001, three players joined Bonds in doing it. Last year Alex Rodriguez slugged 57 and Jim Thome 52. 
Before this eight-year period, 50 or more home runs were hit in two successive seasons only three times, twice by Babe Ruth.
Adding even more perspective: in the past five seasons, Sammy Sosa has hit more than 60 home runs three times; the 60-homer mark had been reached only twice in baseball history before 1998, the year Mark McGwire and Sosa waged their scintillating home run duel. 
"The numbers are ridiculously inflated," Bob Brenly, the Arizona Diamondbacks' manager, said. "I don't know what you can do. Do you move the fences back? I don't know. Do you move the mound closer to home plate?"
Maybe you don't do anything.
"That's just the way the game is right now," Brenly added. "The fans don't seem to mind at all, so we do what we have to do."
Baseball people offered a variety of reasons for the 50 phenomenon, including the speculation about steroids and dietary supplements. They also acknowledged difficulty in relating today's home run developments to past times.
Some former players, not surprisingly, felt that the artificial reasons for the new numbers are unfair to the hitters who established the career-leading totals in what they feel were purer days.
But no one wanted to propose that baseball should devise a new system to evaluate home runs compared with the prior highest totals.
"I've been re-evaluating home runs forever," said Bob Boone, a former catcher who is manager of the Cincinnati Reds. "Fifty now is what 40 used to be. Thirty now is what 20 used to be." But, he added, "I don't compare them."
Andy MacPhail, the Chicago Cubs' president, suggested that these things should be taken in stride. 
"The game evolves," he said. "It's always changing, always evolving. This is one aspect of it."
And, don't get too caught up in the dramatic increase of home run hitting, St. Louis Manager Tony La Russa suggested, because the rise will most likely soon abate.
"I just think there will be some natural corrections," he said. "It will be interesting to see how many hit 50 this year. There is an issue about how you equate the last few years of home run hitting versus the Hank Aaron-Roger Maris-Willie Mays type. I think there are some extras working for hitters. Some of those will not be there."
La Russa declined to expand. "I don't want to get specific," he said.
But he wasn't talking about the smaller parks, the poorer pitching, the legitimately bigger and stronger hitters, the lighter bats or the allegedly livelier balls. 
No one is willing to talk about steroids and specific home run hitters. But suspicions abound.
During a recent visit to the Oakland Athletics camp, Cecil Fielder said steroids are a problem but rejected the percentages that some current and former players have claimed use them. 
But, he said, "I hit 50 home runs one year when no one was hitting 50 home runs. Now everybody, even the little guys, are hitting 50 home runs."
Fielder hit 51 home runs in 1990, the 18th time a major leaguer had reached 50, the first time in 13 years and only the second in a quarter century.
Then, in 1995, Albert Belle hit 50, and there was no holding the hitters. In the next four seasons McGwire slugged 52, 58, 70 and 65. Sosa had a four-year run, too, hitting 66, 63, 50 and 64. Ken Griffey hit 56 in successive seasons. 
Brady Anderson's 50 in 1996 was the most bizarre total. In approximately the same number of at-bats, he hit 16 the season before and 18 the season after. His next highest total to 50 was 24.
Luis Gonzalez went from a career-high 31 in 2000 to 57 the next year.
"During my 50 homers I remember, in San Francisco, half the crowd was yelling 'steroids,' at me and the other half was yelling 'stick man,"' recalled the sinewy Gonzalez, whom no one would mistake for a steroids user.
It isn't just the individual season totals that have grabbed peoples' attention. This season especially will focus attention on career totals. With 168 home runs in the past three seasons, Bonds has catapulted to fourth on the career list with 613, trailing only Aaron (755), Ruth (714) and Mays (660). And the 500 home run circle, which has only 17 members, can easily grow by four this season. Sosa has 499, Rafael Palmeiro 490, Fred McGriff 478 and Griffey 468.
Frank Robinson, who is fifth on the career list with 586, was asked if he is bothered that the home run explosion may cause people to undervalue previous highs.
"It shows a disrespect to players who put those numbers up in the past, naturally," Robinson, now the Montreal Expos manager, said. "Guys are using supplements to make themselves better and bigger and stronger. Over time, players like the Aarons and the Mayses won't get their just due."
Home run inflation could also affect the way Hall of Fame voters view career totals. Voters have always accepted 500 as automatic fame certification, but by the time Palmeiro and McGriff appear on the ballot, they may look at that number differently. 
Decisions could be based on a voter's perception of the player. If the player was suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs, for instance, he might lose votes. On the other hand, voters will have to consider the evolution of the game..
"The culture of the game has changed," the Cubs' MacPhail said. "It used to be that strikeouts were humiliating and unacceptable. Today it's more acceptable. Close to 25 percent of the outs are strikeouts. You have players taking a 2-2 swing today they didn't take 20 years ago. Putting the ball in play is not in favor as it once was."
At 40, Jamie Moyer is one of the older players in the major leagues, but even he has no firsthand knowledge of what the game used to be.
"I can't look back 25, 30 years," Moyer, a pitcher for Seattle, said. "But I've got to believe from watching old clips, guys gave themselves up more to move the runner. There's more emphasis on home runs now." 
One of the most noticeable differences in home runs, Moyer said, is the direction they take.
"Twenty-five, 30 years ago," he said, "did guys drive the ball out of the ballpark the opposite way as much as they do today? Probably not. What does that tell you? To me, it says they're looking for a ball over the plate more."
Moyer's former manager confirmed his suspicion.
"The biggest thing to me," Lou Piniella said, "is when I played there were a handful of players who could hit the ball with consistency over the center-field wall or to the opposite field. Now that list has grown immensely. At times you see four, five, six home runs hit in a game and nothing is hit to the pull fields. They're hit either the opposite way or to the center part of the field."
Players can more readily hit balls over opposite-field fences because they are bigger and stronger. Some may be bigger and stronger because of steroids and supplements, but most players work for their size.
"There's a lot of work being done in the weight room," Moyer said. "You can't say it's all steroids."
Alex Rodriguez sat in the Texas Rangers' clubhouse in the new spring training complex in Surprise, Ariz., and talked about conditioning and weight work.
"You look back 20 years ago, you come to a place like this, nowhere could you find a weight room," he said. "Now the first thing they do when they build a place like this is build a weight room. The nature of the game has changed completely."
Bigger salaries have eliminated the need for off-season jobs and have provided inducement to work out during the winter as well.
Rodriguez, who has hit 109 home runs the past two seasons, is a prime example of the change in size of today's players.
"There was only one Cal Ripken and Ernie Banks," he said, referring to the size of those shortstops. "Now you're seeing Jeter, Rodriguez, Garciaparra. These are big people playing shortstop. That's not normal. Is there going to be a 6-8 shortstop in the year 2030? I hope not. But at the pace we're going, that's where it's going."
While players are growing, parks are shrinking. Most new parks have been deliberately made smaller than their predecessors, to make them more intimate for fans. Their size has enhanced home run hitting.
"When I was playing," Robinson said, "we'd go into team meetings and the manager would say, 'When you need an out, make the guy hit it to the big part of the ballpark.' Today there's no such thing. It's not because the hitters are hitting the ball over the center-field fence. Center-field fences are much shorter; the gaps are much shorter."
He added: "The Polo Grounds was a cab ride to center field. There's no place for a pitcher today to get hitters out."
Players have introduced other changes. Jeff Torborg, the Florida Marlins manager, said he used a 34-inch, 32-ounce bat, "which is not a little bat now, and Willie Mays picked it up and said, 'I pick my teeth with this."'
Today's players use smaller and lighter bats, the better to generate bat speed, which in turn creates power. Boone recalled that Fred Lynn, in the late 70's, initiated that trend. 
"E equals MC squared," Boone said. "Reduced mass, but you get more velocity."
Piniella explained that the faster a player can get his bat to the hitting area "the more power you're going to have." And the more power a hitter has, the wealthier he can become.
"Guys who can hit home runs with frequency are like heavyweight boxers," Piniella said. "They make more than the middleweights and the lightweights."
All of the changes raise the question of how Babe Ruth would have fared if he were playing today with the new technology and training.
"I don't know if he would take advantage of it," Brenly said. "He'd take advantage of that 2 a.m. closing time. I don't know if Babe would have the work ethic to hit it as hard as some of these guys do."

HEADLINE: Preview 03: A TEAM TO WATCH; 
Twins Are Looking to Win A Title, Not Recognition

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
The dutiful fan had his baseball cards wrapped in sheets of plastic this spring as he waited beside the Minnesota Twins' dugout for autographs. But whenever one of the Twins approached, the fan cheated to determine his identity. He peeked down at his cards a few times before he was confident enough to holler for "Mr. Mientkiewicz" or "Mr. Guzman" or "Mr. Koskie."
 The plucky, contraction-dodging Twins reached the American League Championship Series last season before losing to the Anaheim Angels, the eventual World Series champions, but a part of them that remains refreshingly anonymous. The cautious fan was a fitting metaphor for the Twins because there are times when casual observers look at them and still wonder who they are. 
 The Twins do not care about recognition. Let the Yankees be showered with attention for investing $53 million in a Japanese outfielder and a Cuban pitcher; that amount was the equivalent of Minnesota's entire payroll last season. Let everyone marvel about how arduous it is to play in the treacherous A.L. West. Meanwhile, the Twins, who hung around longer than any A.L. club except the Angels a year ago, will muddle along, winning and hoping. 
Maybe this is the magical season when the Twins shed another layer of their anonymity and take one or two more steps. The first big step would mean getting to the World Series, and the second would mean winning it. The Twins, who play in the Charmin-soft Central Division, stress that they are not a one-season wonder and believe they can do what the Angels did and win it all.
"We're pretty much the same team," catcher A.J. Pierzynski said. "We've gained a year's worth of good experience, we've grown closer and matured a little bit, and hopefully we've learned from what happened last year. We think we can improve on it and have a chance to win the World Series."
When the Angels won the first title in their 42-season history, it was a wonderful tale about a fundamentally sound team that showed what playing properly can accomplish. The Angels took pitches, they rarely struck out, they made productive outs, they had a deep bullpen that obscured an ordinary rotation and they had a feisty attitude. 
The Angels also had a reasonable payroll of $77.3 million, almost $100 million less than the Yankees', so their improbable triumph gave hope to a number of teams. "If the Angels could win a title, why not us?" was a question uttered in several spring training camps. The Angels, the Twins ($53.8 million) and the Oakland Athletics ($65.4 million) all joined the Yankees ($171.3 million) in the postseason, three small spenders and one big spender.
But Commissioner Bud Selig called the success of the Twins, the Angels and the A's, who have been in the postseason for three straight years, an aberration. Selig probably thought he needed to say that because the collective bargaining agreement reached last August increased the revenue sharing from the large market to the small market clubs, and he believes those changes were essential.
Now the Angels are the model for some teams. Play baseball the right way and do it economically, which the Twins have been doing. Even after signing Torii Hunter to a four-year, $32 million deal and Jacque Jones to a two-year, $7.1 million contract and adding pitcher Kenny Rogers for $2 million to replace the injured Eric Milton, the Twins will still have one of the lowest payrolls in the major leagues.
The Twins, like the Angels, embody the team concept. The Yankees have a deep rotation, a deep bullpen and a stacked lineup. The Twins are different. No player drove in more than 94 runs. No pitcher won more than 15 games. Hunter, a spectacular center fielder, is their one superstar. 
The Twins have sturdy pitching and will rarely hurt themselves on defense; they made only 74 errors, the least in the majors. Hunter and first baseman Doug Mientkiewicz are Gold Glove winners, and shortstop Cristian Guzman and third baseman Corey Koskie are reliable. The Twins were not the Angels, but they want to be just like the Angels. 
"It just goes to show you that you don't need to have a huge payroll to be successful," infielder Denny Hocking said. "I think the Angels were such a phenomenal team. They were in a pennant race the whole month of September. They were used to that atmosphere and, when it came time for the playoffs, they were ready. I think they caught the Yankees by surprise."
Can that situation unfold again? In 2001, the Angels won 75 games and finished 41 games out of first place. Even pitcher Jarrod Washburn conceded that it would have been a bit presumptuous for the Angels to focus on the World Series. But once the 2002 season started and the Angels overcame a sluggish first few weeks, their confidence soared. 
"What we did is play baseball," Anaheim's Tim Salmon said. "That's the way baseball is supposed to be played. The challenge is putting things together and doing it again."
Paul Molitor, a future Hall of Famer who is a minor league coordinator for the Twins, said bluntly that another low payroll team was unlikely to repeat what the Angels did because history shows higher payroll teams usually dominate in the postseason. Between 1995 and 2001, teams from the bottom two quartiles of the payroll scale won 5 of 224 postseason games. The Twins almost matched that by winning four postseason games in 2002. 
Still, Molitor -- the one man in uniform the autograph-seeking fan recognized without peeking at his cards -- explained grudgingly that the opportunities for teams with lower payrolls to win a title are rare. Doing what Anaheim did in winning the World Series will be difficult for the Angels to repeat and difficult for the Twins to mimic, too. 
"We got some experience, we kept our players, but the odds aren't in your favor," Molitor said. "Realistically, our players might not say that. But that's how I feel."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Needs Technology Programs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Much attention has been drawn to Governor McGreevey's proposed cuts in financing for the arts (Feb. 23, March 16) but little to his plan for equally severe cuts to science and technology programs. 
If approved by the Legislature, the plan will eliminate all state investments in research and development programs that bring academic scientists at our universities together with industry researchers and engineers while also spinning out new businesses and providing other benefits to our economy. 
 The plan will eliminate federally supported programs on our university campuses and operating support for all 11 of our business incubators, entrepreneurial centers that have helped create new businesses for 18 years, especially in urban areas. It will also eliminate the entire staff and operations of the Commission on Science and Technology, of which I am the executive director. This is the state agency that administers and monitors these programs, which historically have obtained at least $3 in nonstate funds for every $1 invested by the commission. 
While we are aware of the budget crisis facing our state, New Jersey needs these programs to maintain its competitive position in a technology-based and technology-driven economy.

John V. Tesoriero
Trenton

HEADLINE: Abuse of Horses Is a Growing Problem 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Tough Times for the State Animal" (Feb. 23): 
 Of importance when speaking of "tough times" for horses is the work of New Jersey's private, nonprofit equine-rescue farms. The state has no rescue system in place for horses in crises. Sadly, in today's economy the number of horses neglected and abused grows steadily, and the rescue farms are bombarded daily with requests to provide food and shelter for these animals. The financial burden is great, and the demand for shelter is shrinking. One such farm, Mylestone Equine Rescue, in Phillipsburg, can be reached at (908)995-9300 or www.mylestone.org.

Henrietta Schleif
Basking Ridge

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
For Young Artists, a Show With Just the Right Slant

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO 

 BODY:
THE people at Real Art Ways in Hartford have been pestering me for weeks to come see this show. Now I know why, for it's a corker. Eungie Joo, the curator, has assembled, under the shady title "Lean To," a compelling array of works by seven young and emerging artists. All but one are from New York City.
 A lean-to is a temporary shelter, either free-standing or supported by one wall of a larger building. It is usually makeshift, economical and provisionary. The same goes for the works in this show, which exude a hip urbanity. Herein lies their appeal. 
 Take Mark Bradford's "Burn Baby Burn" (2002), a whopper of a painting made from strips of color copier paper, chunks of metal and singed squares of industrial tissue, the kind used for perm rollers in hairdressing salons, embedded in gesso, then covered in a light lacquer glaze. The overall effect is reminiscent of those big, coolly expressive New York abstracts of the 1960's, yet with a vernacular quality that hints at the curbside grittiness of Pop. 
"Double Stretch," made this year also by Mr. Bradford, is similarly beguiling. A casual glance at this pot-au-feu of a painting on mesh yields a dizzying array of optical effects. After more prolonged viewing, what appeared at first to be a random accretion of colors and shapes begins to cohere into a solid picture. Although only 40, Mr. Bradford is set to pass slower traffic on the road to fame.
Deborah Grant's paintings have the playful, cartoonish quality of Pop art. But her imagery is laced with angst, deriving mostly from painful memories of school dormitories, mental wards, crack dwellings, dead end bars and the people she met there. Imagine Roy Lichtenstein channeling Jean-Michel Basquiat, and you've got an idea of the ferocious graphic quality of these works. Imagine Raymond Pettibon meets Marilyn Manson, and you've got an idea of the content. Yikes! 
Over in the far room is a video by Paul Chan, a new media artist from New York City. Mr. Chan is best known for his placard-waving, political/aesthetic web page for longhairs, National Philistine, and recently spent a month in Baghdad as a member of a group working to end sanctions against Iraq. His video samples radio broadcasts and television news footage to satirize the Bush cabinet and its policy on Iraq. Although mischievous, it's a hoot.
The public to which Mr. Chan's video speaks is mostly anti-war, although whatever your views on the conflict, you cannot help laughing at what appears to be the voice of Colin Powell reading from the writings of Michel Foucault on the inevitability of history, or Condoleeza Rice at the front line dictating a letter to her family back home. My favorite is a voice sample of Donald Rumsfeld saying, "We must learn to live with low-density hope." 
One can find all manner of references to other artists in the works in this show. Perhaps the most obvious are Andrew Rogers' snapshots of mundane urban landscapes. There's been so much of this dimly lighted, painfully banal photography over the last few years that the entire genre is starting to wear a little thin. Much of this sort of work will surely sink like a stone in the next few years. 
Out on his own, working in three dimensions, is Isami Ching. His contribution consists of a huge plastic funnel hanging from the ceiling beneath a skylight. Aside from being beautiful, its design and placement reveal a keen formal and conceptual intelligence. Light streams through the skylight to illuminate the vessel. At other, rather more rare, moments, it begins to glow. 
Just as young artists get ahead by showing whenever and wherever they can, young curators get to be players in the art world by also adopting a scattergun approach. The logic goes something like this: The more shows you do, the more you get your name about town, build up your curriculum vitae and have a shot at a coveted museum post. 
Perhaps that's what Ms. Joo was thinking when she was selecting a theme and artists for "Lean To," while at the same time arranging another exhibition, "Lean," at the ISE Cultural Foundation in New York City. The inspiration for both shows is pretty much the same, as are a bunch of the artists. Hartford is some way from New York, but it's not so far that nobody will notice.
"Lean To" is at Real Art Ways, 56 Arbor Street, Hartford, through April 27. Information: www.realartways.org. or (860)232-1006.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mark Bradford's "Burn Baby Burn," above, Deborah Grant's "History of Coercion 101," left, and Isami Ching's sculpture are on display at Real Art Ways in Hartford. (John Groo)

HEADLINE: Flour Power 

BYLINE:  By Ann Hodgman; Ann Hodgman is the author of "One Bite Won't Kill You," a book of recipes for children.

 BODY:
How small and humble this book is to have made such a big difference. Look at it: the title, "The Tassajara Bread Book," in calligraphic type. The circular cover drawing -- a loaf of bread and sunflowers -- like something from a small-town literary magazine. The cover itself, made of coarse brown paper. Even the text, printed in brown. You feel as though the book should be sitting on a butcher-block kitchen counter 30 years ago, next to an avocado pit that someone's trying to sprout in a jar of water. 
 The 30-years part would be right, anyway. "The Tassajara Bread Book" was written in the late 1960's by a young Zen student named Edward Espe Brown, who lived and worked at a Zen retreat named Tassajara, in Monterey County, Calif. His manuscript was published in 1970 by the Shambhala press in Berkeley, Calif. The book began with a $100 advance and a 3,000-copy printing. Now there are 750,000 copies in print, and it still sells a steady 3,000 copies every year. Many people consider it the bible of bread baking, one of the most influential cookbooks ever, an inspiration not only to bakers and chefs but also to an entire generation of food writers. The same bread and sunflowers remain on the cover. And Brown, who was ordained as a Zen priest in 1971, is still working to disseminate his vision of what we could be, if we could remember how to use our hands. 
 Those of us who remember baking our first bread in the 60's remember very, very heavy bread. When you're using whole grains for the first time and you're using yeast for the first time and you can't believe that the bread dough actually has to double in bulk before you bake it -- because no matter how pure and virtuous bread baking is, whoever heard of a food you have to wait for? -- well, like the majority of first-time bakers in the 60's, you turn out loaves that could be used to build forts. This somehow seems to add to the bread's moral worth, but worthiness isn't much fun to eat.
"The Tassajara Bread Book" changed that. Not that our parents' food tomes, like "The Joy of Cooking," didn't have bread recipes. But with their primly efficient format and their teeny industrial illustrations, they were too much like something you'd use in home-economics classes. Here, on the other hand, was a book that began:
"Dedicated
with respect and appreciation
to all my teachers
past, present and future:
gods, men, and demons; 
beings, animate and inanimate, 
living and dead, alive and dying.
Rock and water
wind and tree
bread dough rising
Vastly all
are patient with me."
The book was illustrated with drawings of laughing Buddhas, cats and sandals. It told you not to become intimidated by bread dough, and that getting angry at yeast's failings "does not help."
The book was a perfect fit for the times (one fan wrote that learning to make his own bread had liberated him from corporate America) and an ongoing addition to Tassajara's operating budget.
Which was why it was written in the first place. "I was so grateful," Brown says now, "for the opportunities I had to practice Zen at Tassajara," where he studied with Shunryu Suzuki Roshi. "Suzuki Roshi was not a particularly demonstrative person, but I know that he loved me as much as anybody ever has -- and just for who I was, not for being a great cook. I wanted to do something to repay my tremendous feeling of gratitude, and I thought maybe a book about making bread would earn some money for the Zen center and be a nice thing to do for people."
There was a reason for such gratitude. When Brown was 3, his mother died. Three days later, Brown and his older brother, Dwite, were placed in an orphanage in San Anselmo, Calif., by their grief-stricken father. It was the only way he could continue to regularly see his sons, who otherwise would have had to live with relatives in South Dakota. Edward Brown was the youngest child who had ever lived there. "My father told me that when I first got to the orphanage, I just sat on a rocking chair on the porch all day long," he says. "I wouldn't talk or play with the other kids. Now I look at that and I think, Wow, my first meditation." Four years later, Brown's father remarried, and the boys were able to return home. "Still, I do have the feeling sometimes that I've spent a good deal of my life figuring out how to be my own mother. I think my cooking and baking can be seen in that light."
A happier inspiration came a few years later, when Brown and his brother visited their aunt in Washington, D.C., and she made them the first homemade bread they'd ever tasted. "The house smelled so amazing when we'd get back from sightseeing -- so friendly and appetizing. Even at that age, I thought: What's happened in our culture? Why aren't we eating bread like this? What's gone wrong here? I basically decided, I'm going to do this. I'm going to share this with people. There's no reason we shouldn't have something this delicious in our lives." (Later Dwite would say, "What I remember about that trip is the Smithfield ham, but it didn't change my life.")
In the summer of 1967, Brown took a job as a dishwasher at Tassajara. "I asked the cooks right away if they could teach me to make bread, and they said, 'Well, of course.' It meant less work for them. For me, it was like love. I started making the bread all the time." Later that summer, when one of the cooks quit, Tassajara's owners invited Brown to be a cook. Gradually he began asking the other people in the kitchen to write down their recipes, and things grew from there.
The bread book's first printing sold out immediately, and it continued to sell so well that it was printed in two subsequent editions, slightly revised, with additional recipes for things like desserts and flavored butter. "In 1985, I realized, to my horror, that I'd written the whole book in Suzuki Roshi English, leaving out the articles and pronouns," Brown says. "I decided to put them back in."
"Tassajara Cooking," the book's sequel, came out in 1973, two years after Suzuki Roshi died, "and we had learned how to speak English again." The Tassajara cookbooks were followed by "The Greens Cookbook," written with Deborah Madison, and the tragically out-of-print "Tomato Blessings and Radish Teachings." Brown also edited a collection of Suzuki Roshi's lectures, called "Not Always So."
Asked what he thinks about bread machines, Brown pauses. "I try to be tolerant," he says after another pause. "I've had some pretty decent bread from bread machines. But I'm convinced that working with your hands is fundamentally nourishing. As the Shakers said, work is a gift to the person doing the work. Why turn it down? When you knead bread, you're kneading all the channels and acupuncture points in your hands. Whether or not you call that a spiritual benefit or just a physiological one, doing something with your hands is just incredibly invigorating to your whole body."
After Tassajara, Brown worked at San Francisco's Greens Restaurant in virtually every capacity, from busboy to wine buyer to manager. He mainly teaches now: occasional vegetarian-cooking classes, frequent meditation and yoga workshops. He is still asking, "What's gone wrong here?" But being an idealist is harder in these pinched days. Apart from his distress over the nation's politics, he worries that America has lost its most fundamental independence. "When I was growing up," he says, "nobody could show me how to bake bread -- and it's only gotten worse. It seems such a shame that as a culture we don't teach our children about the basic things in life -- bread making, gardening, sewing -- and the value of work. At some point, all these things got to be beneath our dignity. If you can't work with your hands, you lose the richness of your life and the sense of being productive."
He continues: "In my book, I wanted in a small way to share the fact that you could actually learn skills in your life that would help you become able to take care of yourself. It's so simple. It's such a clear vision. People have the capacity to cook and garden and farm, and we don't use it. It's very sad to me that it's come to this."
But he keeps baking. And he rarely ends a conversation with Goodbye. Instead, he says, "Blessings." 

Tassajara's Flaky Biscuits

1 cup unbleached white flour
1 cup whole-wheat flour
3 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 cup butter or margarine
2 eggs
1/2 cup milk.
1. Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Combine flours, baking powder and salt. Cut butter or margarine into dry ingredients with a pastry cutter or two knives, or rub gently between hands until pea-size pieces are formed. 
2. Make a well in the center and add the eggs and milk. Beat the eggs and milk with a fork until smooth. Continue stirring with the fork, gradually incorporating flour until it is all moistened. 
3. On a floured board, knead the dough just enough to bring it together. Roll the dough into a rectangle 1/2-inch thick. Fold in thirds. Turn the dough a quarter-turn and repeat, rolling and folding. Repeat once more. (The rolling and folding make a flakier biscuit.)
4. Roll out the dough again to a 1/2-inch thickness. Cut into rounds with a floured cutter or glass. Place on an ungreased cookie sheet and bake at 450 degrees for 8 to 10 minutes, until the bottoms are lightly browned and the tops slightly golden. Do not overbake.
Yield: 12 to16 biscuits.
Note: for a variation, add 1/2 cup roasted sesame or sunflower seeds to the dry ingredients.

HEADLINE: The Global Villain 

BYLINE:  By Barry Gewen; Barry Gewen is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:
 BEING AMERICA
Liberty, Commerce, and Violence
in an American World.
By Jedediah Purdy.
337 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.
 JEDEDIAH PURDY was the wunderkind du jour a few years ago. In 1999, when he was 24, he published "For Common Things: Irony, Trust, and Commitment in America Today," an ambitious assault on his own generation for its narcissism and self-absorption. Purdy's target was the ironic sensibility that, he said, had infected just about everyone under 35; his arch villain was Jerry Seinfeld, "irony incarnate." In a cynical Seinfeldian world -- also the world of "Saturday Night Live" and "Beavis and Butt-head" -- nothing mattered, nothing was true; it was "all spin, all the way down." "For Common Things" was a courageous book, not only because it was articulating a decidedly unfashionable view but also because it is hard to attack irony without sounding like a pill. Purdy could sound like a pill. His calls for sincerity and mutual obligation blurred all too readily into a posture of self-righteousness. Still, in an age bounded by Madonna and Eminem, it was refreshing to encounter a young, secular author making an impassioned appeal for moral commitment and social responsibility.
His second book, "Being America: Liberty, Commerce, and Violence in an American World," shows that Purdy has lost none of his ambition. His theme now is globalization in its social, economic and, above all, intellectual aspects, his goal an answer to the oft-repeated question "Why do they hate us?" In 2001 Purdy went to see for himself, traveling through the Middle East and Asia, talking to students, business executives, ethnic nationalists, religious fanatics. This is his report on the bad news.
Globalization, Purdy says, has produced disruption everywhere, an unavoidable "tectonic" shift. Traditions have been uprooted, institutions overturned, populations left untethered and resentful. Does this sound familiar? It should. Marxism may be dead, but Marx's picture of the awful destructiveness wrought by free markets still has force, and his famous comment on the psychological impact of capitalism could be Purdy's as well: "All that is solid melts into air." But Purdy diverges from Marx in two key ways. First, he does not have a 19th-century faith in the inevitability of progress. Where Marx was confident that the proletariat would usher in a golden age, Purdy sees a still unresolved conflict between two tendencies, one liberal and tolerant, the other illiberal, fanatical and violent. These tendencies, he is keen to point out, exist side by side within countries, even within the same person. 
Second, where Marx understood history to be driven by inexorable economic forces, Purdy gives those forces an American face. Throughout the world, he writes, globalization is viewed as an American phenomenon, so that when difficulties emerge or conditions turn sour, fairly or unfairly, the United States is blamed. Consequently, it is for America, the "prophetic nation," to show the way, to ensure that the values of freedom and openness prevail over religious and nationalistic extremism. Greatness has been thrust upon us.
Purdy is at his best describing the people he met on his travels. One might well object that there is nothing representative about them: he talks to the Bill Gates of India; he manages to find a non-Coptic Christian family in Egypt (who complained that the Americans weren't as tough on Muslims as the Israelis were). But for somebody who lives so much in his head, Purdy is a surprisingly sharp observer. Mainly, what he observes is paradox, contradiction -- the woman lawyer in Cairo, Westernized in every way except that she has refound her Islamic faith and declares that if Osama bin Laden had attacked the White House, "no one could have said it was murder"; or the cosmopolitan gay AIDS activist in Bombay, who believes Hinduism "needs a whip" to use against the Muslims; or the upwardly mobile students at Beijing University who see through the government's Marxist rhetoric and tell Purdy that what China requires is "to be ruled by good kings."
Purdy's eye for contradiction extends beyond individuals. He has the ability to perceive the mix of good and bad in most things. Capitalism sets people free; it also destroys lives. Nationalism provides inspiration and ideals, a sense of shared purpose. But because it is exclusionary, setting "us" against "them," it is "intrinsically violent." This bifurcated outlook is one of Purdy's strengths. He is not likely ever to go off the deep end. He may support liberal democracy as the best solution yet devised for mankind's problems, but he understands that one size does not fit all. Americans make a mistake when they try to apply their model everywhere, he says; institutions and social structures must be shaped to particular circumstances. All true.
NEVERTHELESS, this is not an easy book to like. It's so diffuse that you never know what's coming next. A conversation with Indonesian environmentalists segues into a critique of Christian evangelicalism; a chapter on Benetton's advertising (of all things) is followed by one on Subcomandante Marcos and the Mexican Zapatistas. Purdy can be preachy, homiletic. He is fond of the disingenuous "we," which seems to include everyone but himself, as in: "We do not pause to consider that we bearers of civilization might display some barbarism ourselves." Purdy pauses -- you can count on it. He also enjoys showing off his learning: within the space of eight pages he cites the Buddha, St. Augustine, Plato, Montesquieu, Adam Smith, Tocqueville, John Winthrop, Alexander Hamilton, Abraham Lincoln, Walt Whitman, Michael Oakeshott and Ralph Waldo Emerson.
Purdy knows what the big questions are. It's the answers that give him trouble. In his closing chapters he offers some suggestions for healing global divisions, and what they come down to is that the wealthy countries should play nice. They should be "generous and fair-minded," "principled" and "humane." The United States in particular will have to put its house in order and learn to lead by example. The whole world is watching, and unless America becomes a paragon of liberal democracy, the forces of illiberalism will grow. "In the end," he writes, "peoples cannot take responsibility for each other; but they serve each other when they take responsibility for themselves." Given the dangers we now face from international terrorism and nuclear proliferation, Purdy's stress on tending our own garden seems at least a little beside the point, and some of his readers may see in this a faint family resemblance to the "blame America first" mentality identified years ago by Jeane Kirkpatrick. But a closer relative is the strain of American Protestantism that in the face of external threats emphasizes personal purity and redemption from sin. When the towers fell, Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson looked inward for the cause. Purdy's impulse takes the same form; it's the content that differs. Where Falwell and Robertson worry about school prayer and sex, Purdy worries about poverty and trees.
The problem is that Purdy has a deep aversion to the employment of power. In this he is not very different from many others on the left, and it is a major reason large numbers of Americans look upon liberals (understood here in the narrow sense) as wimps. Do not try to imagine Jedediah Purdy with his head poking out of a tank. At one point he says that "Being America" is a book concerned with varieties of power, but it is more accurately a book about the avoidance of power. The United States is urged to be prudent and recognize its limits, to use its strength to nurture and protect. Be modest, he says. "It is better not to speak too loudly of one's own principles." Purdy himself has certainly learned to speak softly. So far, however, he has failed to grasp the other half of Theodore Roosevelt's equation for surviving in the real world.

LENGTH: 1434 words

HEADLINE: Some Are Cooks, Some Are Dishwashers 

BYLINE:  By Serge Schmemann; Serge Schmemann, a longtime editor and correspondent for The Times, has recently been named editorial page editor of The International Herald Tribune, in Paris.

 BODY:
 OF PARADISE
AND POWER
America and Europe
in the New World Order.
By Robert Kagan.
103 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $18.
 Every now and again, American thinking about foreign affairs is galvanized by an essay that seems to explain the confusing and disparate phenomena of a changing world -- a sort of unifying theory that, whether accepted or rejected, cannot be ignored. Such were George Kennan's "X" article in 1947, which set the strategy for the cold war; Francis Fukuyama's "End of History" article in 1989; and Samuel Huntington's 1993 essay "The Clash of Civilizations." 
These days, the loudest buzz is over Robert Kagan's "Power and Weakness," an essay that appeared in the June-July 2002 issue of Policy Review. It presented the provocative notion that America and Europe are fundamentally different and are becoming more so as the United States amasses extraordinary military might while the Europeans seek to supplant it with international cooperation. 
"That is why on major strategic and international questions today, Americans are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus," Kagan proclaimed at the outset: "They agree on little and understand one another less and less." This, he further declared, could not be attributed to any single factor -- say, the team currently in the White House -- but rather represented a profound, long-developing and enduring divergence. 
It is, indeed, a tantalizing notion, made all the more so by the unexpectedly real anger manifested in the struggle between Washington and Paris over Iraq. The Atlantic has not seemed so wide in decades, and if Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld really believes that France and Germany represent the dying vestiges of an "old Europe," soon to be supplanted by the fresh pro-American legions of Eastern Europe, he'd better take a look at the polls. There's a Europe out there that sees things very differently from the way we do, whether the issue is the Balkans, the environment, the death penalty, bioengineered food, the ABM treaty, the International Court of Justice, the United Nations or how to handle Saddam Hussein. These differences, moreover, have steadily deteriorated into mutual mudslinging: Europeans see Americans as cowboys, belligerent and crude; Americans dismiss Europeans as decadent, spent and weak-willed. 
The fact that Kagan published his essay months before Washington and Paris squared off in the United Nations Security Council makes him seem almost prophetic. Now, in an expanded and revised version, his treatise has been transformed into a slim volume with the new name "Of Paradise and Power: America and Europe in the New World Order." 
The basic idea is that the conclusion of the cold war ended the need to present a common Western front, and allowed a host of fundamental differences to rise to the surface. The Europeans, battered by centuries of warfare, envisioned the post-Soviet future as a world governed by international cooperation and transnational institutions, with the European Union as the shining example. Armed conflict was not to be their tool, but rather the "soft" weapons of economic and diplomatic enticements. At the same time, the United States, with its global reach and responsibility, remained locked in a world where a secure and democratic order depended on the possession and use of arms. The "entirely natural and predictable consequence," Kagan argues, was an American willingness to use that force and European objection to that exercise. 
It is difficult to dispute that Europe and the United States have assumed very different notions of how the post-Soviet world should be ordered. In the debate over the International Criminal Court, even Britain -- which is far more comfortable with the United States as a partner than are the nations of the Continent -- resisted Washington's demands to exempt American peacekeeping troops from the court's reach. At the same time, Europe and the rest of the world have learned that there is a clear limit to how much transnational authority the United States will accept. One can see an obvious irony in the notion that only in collapse did the Soviet Union achieve its goal of dividing the Europeans and Americans. 
But then the cold war put an artificial lid on many a conflict, and Kagan's argument is that the definitive victory of the Western liberal ideal lifted the need to maintain a common Western front. "The existence of Muslim fundamentalism may force Americans and Europeans to defend themselves against devastating attack, and even to cooperate in providing a common defense," he writes. "But it does not force 'the West' to prove itself unified and coherent, as Soviet Communism once had." 
Kagan has drawn fire when he suggests that the enormous disparity of power has led Europe to duck responsibility for policing a dangerous world of terrorists, rogue nations and failed states, or to settle for what one European describes as a division of labor that consists of Americans "making the dinner" and the Europeans "doing the dishes." Kagan serves up an especially provocative image when he compares the United States and Europe to two men confronting a dangerous bear, one armed only with a knife and the other with a rifle. It is psychologically inevitable, he declares, that the one with the knife will choose to lie low, while the one with the gun will find greater security in trying to shoot the bear. "This perfectly normal human psychology has driven a wedge between the United States and Europe," he asserts. 
The analysis comes close to giving an implicit approval to the Bush administration's furious pursuit of Saddam Hussein as a "perfectly normal" course of action, while relegating Europeans to permanent timidity in a world teeming with rogue bears. But if Kagan's analogy were in fact accurate, would not the Europeans cheer the American hunter on? Is not the real issue here that the Europeans fear the unconstrained hunter -- and specifically George W. Bush -- more than they fear the bear? And is the bear that Bush decided to pursue the real threat out there? 
However compelling Kagan's arguments about the causes and effects of the divergence of Europe and the United States, it is difficult to accept the idea that the current level of animosity is natural or unavoidable, that it would have been the same no matter who was in the White House or in the Elysee Palace. It is specifically the Bush administration that put forth a military doctrine calling for overwhelming American military superiority unto eternity, that has been neglecting the Israeli-Palestinian struggle as it spins out of control and that consistently pushed for war against Iraq. 
Yes, Democratic administrations have not shied away from using force: the last administration did bomb Iraq, Afghanistan, Sudan and Yugoslavia. Yet Bill Clinton avoided a "you're with us or against us" posture, and managed to remain popular in Europe. The fact that Europe and America are different, and that the United States wields such extraordinary power, should be an argument for a more patient foreign policy. 
For all the balance and careful argument of his essay, Kagan sometimes lets slip a certain frustration with such thinking. "The facile assertion that the United States cannot 'go it alone' is more a hopeful platitude than a description of reality," he writes. "The problem today, if it is a problem, is that the United States can 'go it alone,' and it is hardly surprising that the American superpower should wish to preserve its ability to do so." Yet to argue against "going it alone" is not necessarily a sign of weakness. From a continent that has a clear memory of what war is, it may be wisdom. 
It is probably unfair to Kagan to continue in this manner, summarizing his thoughts and challenging various tidbits, since even in book form his discussion fills only 103 pages, and they are well worth reading. This is especially so since his prose is lucid and elegant, and his arguments are thoughtfully marshaled. A veteran of four years in the State Department, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the author of several books and articles, Kagan demonstrates a confidence and authority that demand serious attention. To disagree with his theses is not to argue against the importance of his essay. On the contrary, generating an intelligent and focused debate is a major function of such works. The true measure of Kagan's small book is that it is hard to imagine any future serious discussion of trans-Atlantic relations or America's role in the world without reference to it.
