HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Bush Peril: Shifting Sand and Fickle Opinion

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29 

 BODY:
Though the scion of a family steeped in politics and public service, George W. Bush remains a young president who came to the White House with relatively limited knowledge of the world and its ills. Yet for two years he has ridden high in public esteem, thanks to confident leadership after Sept. 11 and a surer political touch than his detractors give him credit for.
 Is his luck about to turn in the winds and sands of Iraq? 
 It is quite true, as administration officials say with metronomic regularity, that coalition forces have scored singular successes in the early days of the war, and it is too early to rule out a speedy conclusion. But there have been military surprises and diplomatic shortfalls. 
With every passing day, it is more evident that the failure to obtain permission from Turkey for American troops to cross its territory and open a northern front constituted a diplomatic debacle. With every passing day, it is more evident that the allies made two gross military misjudgments in concluding that coalition forces could safely bypass Basra and Nasiriya and that Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq would rise up against Saddam Hussein.
Already, the commander of American ground forces in the war zone has conceded that the war that they are fighting is not the one they and their officers had foreseen. "Shock and awe" neither shocked nor awed. 
Other potential perils lie ahead. Among senior Washington political figures of both parties, four are mentioned most, as follows:
The war could last so long that the American public loses patience, having been conditioned by predictions from American officials (to quote one of them, Vice President Dick Cheney) that Mr. Hussein's government would prove to be "a house of cards." This has not happened yet; the polls indicate that nearly three of four Americans remain unshaken in their support of Mr. Bush's war policies, despite surprises on the battlefield. The White House believes that public patience, often fickle in recent years, was fortified by 9/11.
Street-by-street fighting in the rubble of Baghdad and other cities -- an eventuality that American strategists have long sought to avoid -- now looks more likely. Mr. Hussein's aides have promised savage resistance. If it materializes, it could produce large coalition casualties, challenging American resolve, and equally large Iraqi civilian casualties, with dire consequences for the coalition's attempt to picture itself as the liberator of Iraq. A heart-rending picture of a wounded 2-year-old was widely published today after a Baghdad market was ripped apart by an explosion Iraqi officials attributed to a coalition bomb.
Saddam Hussein could escape, denying the war effort a definitive totem of victory. It sounds improbable, given the terrifying array of force available to the coalition, but other notorious figures remain at large despite intensive manhunts, including the wartime Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and the Qaeda mastermind, Osama bin Laden.
The hunt for weapons of mass destruction could prove futile -- a development that would make the war look like a wild-goose chase.
Of course, all that is a worst case prognosis. As the war in Afghanistan showed, hard military slogging can give way suddenly to victory. But will victory in Iraq take the shape the United States so badly needs?
Mr. Hussein seems to have decided that he can turn this war into Vietnam Redux. He appears willing to take casualties and to give away territory to gain time. Over time, his strategy implies, he thinks he can isolate the United States and build a coalition of third world nations. Already he is seen as less of an ogre and more of a defender of Islamic honor across the Arab world.
Most Republicans radiate confidence in not only military but also political and diplomatic success.
The longtime Republican pollster Robert Teeter said recently, "If we've gotten rid of Saddam and stabilized Iraq, then things will look pretty good." Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, steadfast in his argument that that is precisely what will happen, told the naysayers on Friday that "it's a bit early for history to be written."
Democrats are more dubious.
"Saddam won't win," said Richard C. Holbrooke, the former United States representative at the United Nations. "Unlike L.B.J. in Vietnam, Bush won't quit. He's a different kind of Texan. He'll escalate and keep escalating. In the end his military strategy will probably succeed in destroying Saddam.
"But it may result in a Muslim jihad against us and our friends. Achieving our narrow objective of regime change may take so long and trigger so many consequences that it's no victory at all. Our ultimate goal, which is promoting stability in the Middle East, may well prove elusive."
Mr. Bush came to office determined, by his own account, not to swagger and not to overreach. "If we're an arrogant nation, they'll resent us," he said in the second presidential debate against Al Gore in 2000. "If we're a humble nation but strong, they'll welcome us." That was a promise to check hubris at the door, an effort to guard against the temptation to believe that because he had such awesome power at his fingertips, he could and should use it to achieve grandiose objectives.
Like remaking a chaotic region in our own democratic image. 
The very term "shock and awe" has a swagger to it, no doubt because it was intended to discourage Mr. Hussein and his circle. But it rings hollow now, and there are other signs of overconfidence. A reserve officer was told some time ago, for example, that he would be needed as part of a provisional government in Baghdad, on March 28.
For the moment, Mr. Bush seems secure. People like him. None of his possible Democratic opponents loom as a major threat, not so far.
Still, for presidents, especially for wartime leaders, political capital can drain quickly from the White House account. After the guns fall silent, voters' eyes turn elsewhere, often to social and economic needs. It happened to Winston Churchill late in World War II, and as this president remembers better than most, it happened to his father, too. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 2, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A front-page news analysis article on Sunday about the political perils faced by President Bush over the war with Iraq misattributed a comment about Saddam Hussein's government being "a house of cards." While some American officials had used the phrase to predict a shorter conflict and a quick collapse of the Iraqi leadership, Vice President Dick Cheney was not among them.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: DAMASCUS; 
Syrian Party Watches Iraq With Unease and Ponders Its Own Fate

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 29 

 BODY:
The provincial Baath Party apparatchik, smoking a hookah in a downtown cafe, lowers his voice under the clack of the backgammon games around him and expresses the kind of criticism that still breeds fear of arrest. 
 "The party might be affected here," the middle-aged man said quietly when asked whether events in Iraq had any echo in Syria. "If things improve for the Iraqis, people will demand reform here, but if things get worse there, of course they won't." 
 In the Arab world, the American-led attack on Iraq generated near-universal condemnation, which grows more vociferous daily. Beyond the fighting, however, both governments and their populations wonder what will eventually emerge in postwar Iraq. 
Perhaps nowhere do the questions about what comes next generate a sharper sense of dread than in neighboring Syria, controlled since 1963 by a rival branch of the same Baath Party that grips Iraq. 
Syrian officials dismiss the notion of any possible effect of the war or any unease that their country might fall into United States sights next. But Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld made such a possibility explicit on Friday by saying Syria risked provoking American ire by allowing military equipment to flow into Iraq.
Syria denied the charge within hours -- unusual alacrity for an Arab government.
"The idea of de-Baathification and other such terms for the region is frightening for the regime," one Syrian professor said. "But the idea that Baath rule would collapse or be washed away is heartening for the intelligentsia."
When Bashar al-Assad, a 36-year-old Internet-savvy doctor, inherited the presidency from his father nearly three years ago, his inaugural address included a vision of a less officially controlled Syria, jettisoning the creaky socialist economy and allowing greater openness. 
But in the ensuing years it has become clearer that he did not mean dismantling the one-party police state his father built. The president revised his remarks in a speech this month, castigating some for interpreting his call for tolerance as a sign of weakness. 
Syria has proved remarkably resistant to change. For example, Mr. Assad issued a law in April 2001 allowing private banks. Not one has been able to cut through the bureaucratic thicket to go into business. Nine outspoken government critics have been silenced with jail terms of up to 10 years. 
In the latest prominent case involving the press, Ibrahim Hamidi, the Damascus correspondent for Al Hayat, one of the Arab world's best newspapers, disappeared into jail in December, accused of breaking Syria's press law by quoting supposed presidential remarks in closed meetings and writing about possible changes in the army. His trial is expected to be secret. 
Syrians undoubtedly hunger for a better life. Government officials say that it is coming and that replacing a system where essentially one man made every decision takes time, especially in the face of repeated regional crises.
"Any change, any reform, is connected to the regional situation," said Saadalla Agha al-Kalaa, the minister of tourism and one of the staunchest reformers brought into the cabinet by Mr. Assad. "I don't think the will for change will increase; the will needed is there."
The Iraq war could prove an especially harsh economic blow. Western governments said Syria received about 200,000 barrels of discounted oil daily from Iraq, shipments the government always denied receiving because they violated United Nations sanctions. 
That alone was worth some $1.5 billion annually in government savings, and Syria last year sold $2 billion in goods to Iraq, many of which it would be hard pressed to sell elsewhere. Thousands of Iraqi government employees were on prewar waiting lists for rickety Syrian kerosene heaters, for example, because they had no choice. The 100 trucks a day that left Syria at Al Tanef crossing alone have dwindled to none. 
It is the lack of any improvement in their lives, unlikely to improve with the war, that really grates. 
"Our standard of living has not changed at all," complained the provincial Baath Party man. He blames corruption for much of it, telling how his local elementary school principal was fired because the man refused to demand bribes from the students that local party hacks pocketed. 
Baath Party officials at all levels admit that rampant corruption and bureaucratic resistance is retarding reform. Even the most senior officials concede that a transformed Iraq might lessen the resistance to change. Some Syrians speculate, however, that it might make the security services more repressive. 
"The regime in Syria fears this war in Iraq because it might affect things here," said Haitham Maleh, a lawyer and human rightsactivist jailed for seven years as a political prisoner and now facing renewed charges of defaming the government. "They don't feel secure." 
Yet like all Syrians interviewed, he adamantly rejects any American role: "We hate the regime here because they are a dictatorship, but we don't agree with any power coming in from outside to change it." 
Syrians are convinced that the United States went to war in no small part because Israel found Iraq a threat. Seeing the way the Iraqis are fighting back, Syrian officials profess confidence that the United States will be preoccupied for far too long to worry about Iraq's neighbors. 
"Let's wait and see how long they will be in Iraq," said Buthaina Shaaban, the spokeswoman for the Syrian Foreign Ministry. "I think they will be in Iraq for a very long time."

HEADLINE: Preview 03 

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish.

A.L. East

NEW YORK YANKEES
Joe Torre, eighth season -- 2002: 103-58, first place
 If the Yankees don't win the World Series this season, it will mark the first time in 10 years that they will have played three complete seasons without a World Series championship. But first things first. 
 The Yankees, playing with the highest-paid collection of baseball players ever, a luxury-tax payroll that could reach $182 million, would have to take an extended vacation not to win their sixth successive division title. 
 The only uncertainty is the bullpen. Mariano Rivera displayed a human streak at times last year, and the Yankees shed the reliable Mike Stanton and Ramiro Mendoza. One of their replacements is Chris Hammond, who will be hard pressed to duplicate the 0.95 earned run average he compiled in 63 games for Atlanta last season.
 Another probable but unlikely reliever, at an $8 million salary, is Jose Contreras, the Cuban defector, who will have to wait for his turn to start.

KEY ADDITIONS -- Hideki Matsui, Jose Contreras
KEY LOSSES -- Mike Stanton, Ramiro Mendoza
KEY TO SEASON -- Winning will keep George Steinbrenner silent.

CLOSER Juan Acevedo (Mariano Rivera d.l.)

BOSTON RED SOX
Grady Little, second season -- 2002: 93-69, second place
 As if they don't take enough heat from their fans, the Red Sox have left themselves open to major second-guessing by passing up the chance to add Bartolo Colon to their starting rotation and by eschewing the traditional role of a bullpen closer.
 They preferred a still untested Casey Fossum to Colon, a 20-game winner, and they opted for a collection of relievers to do the job Ugueth Urbina did for them 40 times last season. They deserve time to see if their decisions work, but if they don't, if they can't reinvent the game, the Boston brain trust will become persona non grata among the Fenway faithful.
 Besides sorting out his relievers and slotting them into the right situations, Grady Little will have to keep track of all of the players he can choose from for first base, third base and designated hitter: Kevin Millar, David Ortiz, Jeremy Giambi, Shea Hillenbrand and Bill Mueller.

KEY ADDITIONS -- Mike Timlin, Ramiro Mendoza
KEY LOSSES -- Ugueth Urbina, Cliff Floyd
KEY TO SEASON -- Their schemes had better work, or it's back to the drawing board.

TORONTO BLUE JAYS
Carlos Tosca, second season -- 2002: 78-84, third place
 The team that a decade ago won two consecutive World Series is still in the early stages of a major reconstruction project. It's a mixed project. The hitters are relatively young: center fielder Vernon Wells, designated hitter Josh Phelps and infielders Eric Hinske, Chris Woodward and Orlando Hudson have a combined six years of major league experience. But the new starting pitchers, Tanyon Sturtze and Cory Lidle, and the trio of catchers are 30-something.
 Roy Halladay, on the other hand, is only 25, and he has become a model of development for the others to follow. After several false starts, Halladay last season was 19-7 with a 2.93 E.R.A., and he led the A.L. in innings pitched with 239.
 The Blue Jays believe they are on the right track. It just might not be a fast track

KEY ADDITIONS -- Cory Lidle, Tanyon Sturtze

BALTIMORE ORIOLES
Mike Hargrove, fourth season -- 2002: 67-95, fourth place
 If two general managers are better than one, the Orioles should enjoy marked improvement this season. But it will probably take a little longer for the efforts of Jim Beattie and Mike Flanagan to pay off in drastic change in the team's fortunes.
 The Orioles have had losing records for five successive seasons. They have to go back to the mid-50's to find the last time that happened to the organization, which moved from St. Louis, where they were the hapless Browns, to Baltimore during that period. 
 The most promising sign from last season was the development of the team's No. 1 starter, Rodrigo Lopez (15-9), and its closer, Jorge Julio (25 saves). But the Orioles didn't have any other young pitchers ready to join that pair, so they took to the free-agent market and signed Omar Daal and Rick Helling. They signed another free agent, Deivi Cruz, to play shortstop.

TAMPA BAY DEVIL RAYS
Lou Piniella, first season -- 2002: 55-106, fifth place
 A general manager's wife once said, "I married George for better or worse but not for lunch." Anita Piniella has husband Lou for lunch.
 When he asked out of the last year of his Seattle contract and said he wanted to be closer to home, he didn't mean Tampa Bay, but the Mariners made sure they took him literally. As a result, one of the game's better managers is stuck with its worst team.
 Piniella will have the youngest and lowest-paid team and very likely the team with the worst record. The question is, will he have his sanity when the season ends?
 The new manager's goal is to break the 70-victory barrier, something the Devil Rays have not done in their five-year existence. He will try to do it with young pitchers like Nick Bierbrodt and a young center fielder like Rocco Baldelli.

Jerry Manuel, sixth season -- 2002: 81-81, second place
 If they reach the playoffs, the White Sox players might want to vote the Red Sox front office a post-season share. The White Sox have Bartolo Colon because the Red Sox fended off the Expos' attempts to trade him to Boston. 
The presence of Colon, a 20-game winner last season with Cleveland and Montreal, gives the starting rotation far more credibility than it had with only Mark Buehrle, a 19-game winner, as a consistently effective starter. Getting Billy Koch as their closer in another trade also enhances the chances of eclipsing the Twins and playing beyond September.
 Should Frank Thomas rediscover the menacing bat that produced career highs of 43 home runs and 143 r.b.i. three seasons ago and combine his production with that of Magglio Ordonez (career highs 38, 135 last season), the White Sox will give the Twins more competition than they would like.

MINNESOTA TWINS
Ron Gardenhire, second season -- 2002: 94-67, first place
 A year ago the Twins, as contraction targets, were frustrated because they didn't know how much longer they would be in existence. Now, as defending division champions, they are frustrated because they feel they squandered a chance to go to the World Series. 
 If a blown lead in the seventh inning of the fifth game of a four-of-seven-game series can inspire the Twins this season, they could be even tougher to beat. 
 They have basically the same team, young but with the added experience of another season and a post-season. Eric Milton, an important member of the starting rotation, is out, possibly for the season, with a knee injury, but the Twins uncharacteristically signed Kenny Rogers as a free agent to replace him.
 Offensively, the Twins could use some improvement. They were the only A.L. playoff team without a hitter who drove in 100 runs or batted better than .300.

KEY ADDITION -- Kenny Rogers

KEY TO SEASON -- They could repeat if their starting pitchers stay healthy and effective.

 A team in transition, the Indians could be surprisingly competitive, or they could have growing pains and fare no better than they did last season, the first of their decline from division-title status.

 Instead of joining Albert Belle, Manny Ramirez, Kenny Lofton and Jim Thome in winning championships, Vizquel is prepared to join Travis Hafner, Ben Broussard, Brandon Phillips and Josh Bard. 
 The Indians are also working young pitchers into their rotation. They have Ricardo Rodriguez and Jason Davis at the start and Brian Tallett in waiting.
 But the players aren't the only youthful part of the new Indians. Eric Wedge, the new manager, is only 35.

 The young players will remain, that is, as long as they do a creditable job: pitchers Runelvys Hernandez, Jeremy Affeldt, Miguel Asencio and Chris George, for example, and designated hitter Ken Harvey.

 The Tigers will go down in history as the epitome of a team that squandered the benefits of a new park. In three seasons at Comerica Park, the Tigers have watched their attendance plummet from 2.5 million to 1.9 million to 1.15 million. 
 At the rate they're going, the Tigers won't reverse the trend because their fans know a dreadful team when they see one. The fans couldn't be blamed for wondering when the expansion team came to town.
 In the interest of saving money, the Tigers gave up their two best hitters from last season, Robert Fick and Randall Simon, and for hitting this season look to young players like Carlos Pena, Ramon Santiago, Brandon Inge, Gene Kingsale and Eric Munson.

 Some baseball people were still shaking their heads this spring. "That was a very hot baseball team and a very disciplined and well-managed baseball team; they were the epitome of getting on a roll," said Ron Gardenhire, whose Minnesota Twins lost to the Angels one step short of the World Series.
 The Angels have kept their championship team intact, but if they again contend this season, as they are expected to do, they won't surprise anyone; after all, they finished 41 games back the previous season.

 Looking back, the Athletics are frustrated because just when they thought it was safe to go to the first round of the playoffs without having to play the Yankees, they encountered the Twins and lost.
 Looking ahead, they are frustrated because their owner has already said that for economic reasons this is the last season they will have Miguel Tejada, their terrific shortstop, who last season had career highs with a .308 batting average, 34 home runs and 131 R.B.I.

SEATTLE MARINERS
Bob Melvin, first season -- 2002: 93-69, third place
 In leaving the Mariners after managing them for 10 years, Lou Piniella said his one regret was that he didn't get Seattle to the World Series. If the Mariners couldn't attain that goal under Piniella, who won a World Series with Cincinnati, can they expect to do it with Bob Melvin as their rookie manager?
 Melvin, bench coach with 2001 World Series champion Arizona, begins basically with the same team Piniella had in his last season. That team, in first place midway through August, stumbled in the final weeks, losing its lead and 17 of 27 games in a monthlong stretch.
 If the Mariners lost anything with Piniella's departure, it brought them Randy Winn, who the last few years has been developing into a solid hitter and should make a strong lineup even stronger. TEXAS RANGERS
Buck Showalter, first year -- 2002:72-90, fourth place
 Given that the Rangers finished 31 games from first last season, Buck Showalter, the new manager, was asked this spring if they could duplicate the Angels' surprising ascent from a 41-game deficit last year.
 "They had something at their disposal from their track record that we're hoping some people become," Showalter said. In other words, the Rangers don't enter the season with the talent the Angels had, so don't expect any huge surprises.
 Showalter has neither the kind of hitters nor the pitching that Mike Scioscia had at his disposal. The Rangers continue to try to improve their pitching, but they still have a long way to go with their starting rotation. Ismael Valdes (8-12 with Texas and Seattle) and John Thomson (9-14 with Colorado and the Mets) are the primary acquisitions.
 They did enhance their relief corps by adding Ugueth Urbina (40 saves with Boston last year) and Esteban Yan (19 with Tampa Bay).

KEY ADDITIONS -- Ismael Valdes, Ugueth Urbina
KEY LOSSES -- Ivan Rodriguez, Kenny Rogers
KEY TO SEASON -- Unless Showalter works some magic, they remain the fourth team in a three-team race.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF; 
Plum Island Strikers Give Up Picketing

BYLINE:  By John Rather 

 BODY:
Saying they have run out of time and money, striking workers at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center have stopped seven months of picketing at an Orient Point ferry terminal that connects to the high-security island laboratory.
 The end of the picketing appeared to signal that the strikers, 76 members of International Union of Operating Engineers Local 30, are losing hope they will regain jobs now held by replacement workers. 
 LB&B Associates of Columbia, Md., which holds a maintenance contract at the government-owned laboratory, hired the replacements after the union went on strike for higher wages in August.
In December, the union agreed to a strike settlement that provided no increases. But the settlement fell apart when LB&B insisted that replacement workers would remain, denying all but a handful of the striking workers their former jobs back.
LB&B's use of replacement workers became controversial after a series of mishaps, including generator failures during losses of power, raised questions about the competence of the replacements to maintain the laboratory, where researchers study highly contagious and deadly animal diseases. 
The strikers gained support from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, Congressman Timothy Bishop, a Democrat from Southampton, and state and local officials who said the union workers had been mistreated and that the use of the replacement workers endangered the public.
But last week the strikers said their union strike benefits and unemployment insurance had run out, compelling them to take or seek jobs elsewhere. "It's been a long winter," said Ronald Grilli of Greenport, one of the strikers. "Tm surprised we stuck it out as long as we did." John Rather

HEADLINE: Out of Jail, In Search Of Someone To Protect 

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
Not yet 35, Israel Adrian Caetano is a rising star of the Argentinian new wave. His second feature, "Bolivia," which played in New York earlier this year, was an examination of poverty and displacement in modern Latin America, as self-assured as it was bleak. "A Red Bear" ("Un Oso Rojo"), his new film, which will be shown tonight at 6 and tomorrow night at 9 as part of the New Directors/New Films series, is a more conventional, genre-bound story, but its combination of toughness and smooth, understated style makes it touching and absorbing. 
 Bear (Julio Chavez), recently released from prison after serving seven years for killing a police officer, is not one for remorse. Within a few days of leaving the penitentiary, he shows that his propensity for violence is undiminished when he mugs a yuppie outside a telephone office. 
 Though he has supposedly paid his debt to society, Oso does, as Bruce Springsteen might put it, have debts that no honest man can pay. He also, like movie thugs from Britain, Hong Kong, Paris and New Jersey, hides a soft core of sentiment under his sociopathic, macho carapace.
Whatever tenderness he is capable of is directed toward his young daughter, Alicia (Agostina Lage), whose first birthday party he abruptly left to commit the crimes that led to his incarceration. Now she and her mother, Natalia (Soledad Villamil), are living on the brink of destitution with Sergio(Luis Machin), a weak-willed, unemployed compulsive gambler. Oso, whose fumbling paternal instincts become stronger as his actions become more decisive, appoints himself their shadowy protector. Their salvation gives him a sense of purpose.
The themes of "A Red Bear" -- payback, sacrifice, honor -- are familiar elements of gangster melodrama, and Mr. Caetano explores them in a mood of bloody, brutal melancholy. Mr. Chavez, bald, stout and smoldering, has a spring-loaded physicality that suggests Vin Diesel with a two-pack habit and a lapsed gym membership. He is not especially handsome, but his blunt, impassive charisma dominates every scene. Half the time you are as scared of him as poor Sergio is; the other half you can't help feeling sorry for the guy.
Mr. Caetano tells Oso's story with flair and economy, lingering over the seamy details and pungent idioms of the Buenos Aires underworld long enough to give the picture a harsh, smoky flavor. As with most tough-guy fables of this kind, you don't know whether the protagonist is heading for ruin or redemption, but that is less a matter of suspense than a philosophical conundrum, and in the end Mr. Caetano has the wit to split the difference.

A RED BEAR

Written and directed by Israel Adrian Caetano; in Spanish, with English subtitles; director of photography, Jorge Guillermo Behnisch; edited by Santiago Ricci; music by Diego Grimblat; art director, Graciela Oderigo; produced by Lita Stantic. Running time: 94 minutes. This film is not rated. Shown tonight at 6 at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, 1941 Broadway, at 65th Street, and tomorrow night at 9 at the Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, as part of the 32nd New Directors/New Films series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film and media of the Museum of Modern Art.

HEADLINE: War's Effect on Retailers Appears to BeMixed 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Shoppers -- buoyed by the spring weather and, analysts say, exhausted by wall-to-wall coverage of the war -- have taken to the nation's malls in surprising numbers. The question is whether they are buying.
 Preliminary figures, issued by Wal-Mart and Federated department stores, which include Bloomingdale's and Macy's, said that sales had slowed during the first week of the war but appeared to be recovering as of last week. A spokeswoman for Lord & Taylor, another large department store chain, said on Friday that the general United States economy, with the war thrown in, had created a challenging retail environment, but that it was "business as usual," with no more drastic markdowns than had been planned before the Iraqi war began. 
 Still, things at Lord & Taylor's Manhattan store were slow at noon yesterday, with a saleswoman standing in front of a mirror trying on sunglasses. In the nearly deserted men's department, a man rejected a tie he was trying on as "too shiny." When asked about shopping during a war, he shrugged. "Life goes on," he said, reaching for another tie. (A sign announced "50 percent off ties already marked down 25 percent.") 
Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, said on Saturday that "people are still shopping for necessities -- trading sweaters for swimsuits -- but there's probably a lot of them who are putting off big purchases." The times are "still scary," she said, "more because of the economy than the war."
Maybe scary, but not positively petrifying. While the Retail Federation will not issue its forecast for 2003 until tomorrow, Ms. Mullin said it was clear that "it's not as bad as people thought it was going to be."
At Thomson First Call, which compiles analysts' predictions, Ken Perkins, a research analyst, said that estimates were starting to come in. Of the major players, "no one is doing really well, " he said, "but no one is doing really badly, either."
At a Wal-Mart in Kingston, N.Y., shoppers were lining up 10 deep at the many checkout counters. In Kansas City, the parking lots at a Best Buy were full, and an advertised combination DVD-VCR machine was sold out, said Mike Green, who specializes in retail consumer products and distribution in the United States for Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, a consulting business. 
"You sure can't tell there's a recession here," he said. "I don't see a big impact. I'm baffled." But Mr. Green agreed with other industry experts who predicted that the situation could change drastically for the worse if the war drags on.
In Portland, Ore., Jennifer Black, a retail analyst for Wells Fargo Securities, said she had been cruising the malls this past weekend, and agreed that business, if not booming, was at least moving. "If your product is right, you're selling it," she said, echoing other analysts.
"In Abercrombie & Fitch, they have a lot of stuff sold out, particularly for girls and teenagers," she said. "It's the baby boomers who aren't shopping as much; they're the ones glued to their televisions." 
Burt Flickinger III, managing director for the Strategic Resource Group, a retail consulting firm, is more pessimistic about the current retail picture.
Mr. Flickinger said that although many malls have customers, they do not appear to be buying. He said several store managers in malls in Phoenix, where he was yesterday, had confirmed that sales this weekend were running below projections.
"At Wal-Mart's new Supercenter in Phoenix, the customer count is way off," he said. "On Friday in the malls here, even PacSun was light; traffic was light even for the March Madness sale at the Foot Locker.
"Saks was virtually empty out here, as was Robinsons-May. Dillard's was deserted, Target was light," Mr. Flickinger said. "Costco was doing pretty good business, but mostly groceries."
There were a few exceptions. In the Arizona Mills mall in Tempe, Ariz., he saw one really thriving business: Steven Spielberg's GameWorks video arcade. Very few people were shopping, he said, "but the teenagers were all playing video games."

HEADLINE: Plans for Cultural Complex At Ground Zero Take Form 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
As plans begin to take shape for a cultural complex at ground zero, American Express has agreed to support a Museum of Freedom that may be built there. The museum would present exhibitions about the terrorist attacks as well as about issues like women's equality andcivil rights.
 An American Express executive said that the company, based in Lower Manhattan, decided to help sponsor the project because of its theme. "This will allow people to learn about freedom and hopefully cherish it more," said the executive, who would speak only anonymously in advance of any announcement. The executive said that the amount of the support had not been determined. 
 The museum would be part of a two-building cultural complex as conceived by Daniel Libeskind, whose design for the 16-acre site was chosen earlier this year. The second building would house a performing arts center, which would probably become the home for the New York City Opera. In addition to its repertory, the opera company would stage musical theater at the hall that it may want to take on the road. 
As envisioned, the first floor of a Museum of Freedom would be devoted to the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001; the second floor would be dedicated to the history of New York City; the third would explore freedom from a national perspective; and the fourth would have an international focus.
"We see it as the intellectual and educational complement to the emotional experience of the spiritual memorial," said Tom A. Bernstein, president of the Chelsea Piers recreation complex, who has been developing the museum over the last year. His partner in Chelsea Piers is Roland W. Betts, a director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the city-state agency formed to direct the rebuilding of the Trade Center site. The Libeskind plan would also include a separate ground zero memorial park.
How much the complex will cost, and how all of it would be paid for remains in question, particularly given the weak economy's effect on charitable giving. Those involved in the cultural possibilities for the site say they expect government and private money will be involved. 
"It would be multiple sources," said John C. Whitehead, chairman of the development corporation. "We would expect an organization that arrives to come with some money and a plan for a balanced operating budget with charitable funds included." Mr. Whitehead also said that tax-free federal Liberty Bonds might be used for one or both buildings and that "as a last resort, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation might have some funds to fill out a gap."
Officials from the New-York Historical Society and the Museum of the City of New York say they are interested in being part of a museum on the site. Kenneth T. Jackson, president of the historical society, met with Mr. Whitehead and Mr. Bernstein about what role his institution might play.
Were the historical society to participate, it would also almost certainly keep its home on Central Park West, but it is undecided whether the Museum of the City of New York would remain in its building on Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street or relocate to ground zero.
The historical society and the museum have been in merger talks for some time. The museum has been trying to determine its future ever since the Bloomberg administration rescinded the offer to move the museum to the Tweed Courthouse, a promise made by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The Tweed, near City Hall, is occupied by the Department of Education.
The museum's director, Robert R. Macdonald, resigned after the Tweed plan fell apart. Susan Henshaw Jones, former president of the National Building Museum in Washington, took over in February and said pooling the resources of the two institutions would create a more complete historical picture of the city. "It's a wonderful venture because both of usare focused on New York and neither has a collection that covers the whole thing," she said.
Mr. Bernstein said the freedom museum would examine social, economic and political issues through archival photographs, documentary footage and artifacts. 
"We want to have some place that gives context and history and meaning to the whole thing," he added. "There is no one museum that tells the story of our freedom."
Also involved in the project are the documentary filmmakers Philip B. Kunhardt Jr. and his brother, Peter W. Kunhardt, who recently produced with their father "Freedom: A History of US," the 16-episode PBS series. The actor Christopher Reeve is also expected to play a role in enlisting the support of the creative community as he did with the Kunhardt series, Mr. Bernstein said.
As to the international component, Mr. Whitehead said there was interest from several institutions. "Various museums around the world have indicated a willingness, indeed a desire for their communities to play a part," he said. "This might be a way for them to do that."
The second cultural building at ground zero would be a performing arts center with City Opera as its probable primary tenant. "There has been no final decision," Mr. Whitehead said. "But I would say it looks favorable now."
Mr. Whitehead said he saw the building as being about five stories high, with a large auditorium on the ground floor and two smaller stages above it, one for music and another for theater. He said that "various people" were interested in managing each of those theaters, but declined to be more specific, adding that rehearsal space and offices would also be included.
The Joyce Theater has expressed interest in being part of a performing arts complex, adding the downtown site to its stages in Chelsea and SoHo.
Irwin Schneiderman, the chairman of City Opera, said that in addition to the regular opera season, he anticipated producing or co-producing musical theater at a new auditorium "to supplement or complement the season."
City Opera on Saturday concluded its run of Stephen Sondheim's "A Little Night Music," and has a long history of producing musical theater. Mr. Schneiderman said the opera house might be used as "a launching platform" for productions that would then tour. "We might take things out on the road," he said.
City Opera has been looking to leave its home in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, which it shares with the New York City Ballet. Because the State Theater was designed to muffle footfalls for dance performances, the opera has long sought a more acoustically appropriate space.
Some City Opera officials would also welcome the chance to move out from under the shadow of its larger, wealthier neighbor, the Metropolitan Opera. 
Considerable questions remain as to whether City Opera's audience would follow the company downtown. City Opera has been conducting demographic surveys to determine how much of a new audience it would gain from places more convenient to Lower Manhattan, like Brooklyn, Long Island and New Jersey.
"Preliminarily, it's looking encouraging," said Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director of City Opera. 
"We know we're going to lose -- not a large percentage, but a percentage of our audience," he added. "And we will need to make up that percentage from elsewhere."
The company's move downtown is very much dependent on the development of transportation in Lower Manhattan, and City Opera executives said these plans for a transit hub looked promising. 
In addition, Lincoln Center executives have expressed doubt about City Opera's ability to sustain itself financially, much less raise money for a new building.
Both Mr. Schneiderman and Mr. Kellogg said there was considerable interest from potential corporate sponsors, though the officials declined to name any possible donors because these talks were still underway. "There are interesting prospects now that we're getting more specific," Mr. Schneiderman said. 
The philanthropist Robert Wilson had previously offered $50 million toward a new City Opera, but said he was "not enthusiastic" about the company moving downtown. Asked whether he would make his contribution if City Opera relocated to ground zero, Mr. Wilson said: "I doubt it, but I'm not sure. They would have to make a case."
City Opera executives are scheduled to meet with officials at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation on April 14. "After the meeting, we will be in a position to make some kind of decision," Mr. Kellogg said. "One has to believe there are enough people who really want us to come downtown to bring that area to life."

HEADLINE: Avid Bourgeois Respectability, Japanese-Style 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
There are moments when "Wild Berries," Miwa Nishikawa's mild comic satire of Japanese family values, suggests a more tempered Asian answer to Todd Solondz's "Happiness." That notorious film, you will recall, lifted up a rock in the plush green lawns of suburban New Jersey and discovered all kinds of crawly creatures feasting on one another.
 Here, the hungers gnawing at its characters insides are not erotic. (There's nothing half as sensational as that movie's portrait of a psychiatrist who is a secret pedophile.) The sins of the family under Ms. Nishikawa's critical microscope have to do with money, pride, and public image. 
 While putting on a desperate show of bourgeois respectability, Yoshiro (Sei Hiraizumi), a middle-age unemployed engineer who is deeply in debt, will do almost anything to stay afloat. His ultimate willingness to let his disgraced son, Shuji (Hiroyuki Miyasako), the black sheep of the family, return and assume management of the purse strings, reveals a fundamental flaw in the family's character.
Without bearing down too heavily, the movie implies that the willingness of Japan's bourgeoisie to indulge in shady financial shenanigans is one of the dirty little secrets of the country's middle-class.
Observing her flailing family and keeping a stiff upper lip is their attractive, strait-laced daughter, Tomoko (Miho Tsumiki), a grade-school teacher who has somehow escaped her parents' moral curse. She is the only household member with a job and a solid sense of ethics. An early scene shows her giving one of her classes a stern lecture about lying and truthfulness. When she begins dating a well-to-do young teacher her own age, her parents, who fantasize her as their rescuer, urge her to snag him as a husband, but it isn't as easy as they imagine.
In the funniest scene, Tomoko brings her boyfriend home for a family dinner that is intended to demonstrate what a happy, normal household she comes from, but everything goes wrong. Much of that humor is slapstick and involves the grotesquely slobbering table manners of Tomoko's senile grandfather, who barges into the gathering and makes a disgusting spectacle of himself. The old man, who appears to have an insatiable appetite, ravenously slurps his food, then complains about how bad it is. He is also prone to seizures that require immediate medication. At one point, his distress signals are pointedly ignored, and he abruptly dies, much to everyone's secret relief. 
It is at the grandfather's funeral that Shuji makes a dramatic surprise appearance and saves the day. When Yoshiro is angrily confronted by a creditor in front of the guests, Shuji poses as a hard-nosed lawyer, issuing ominous counter-threats. Shuji may have been banished for stealing from his father, but his father is so grateful that he welcomes his son as his financial savior.
Once Shuji appears, this grinning, hyperbolic con man takes over the movie and rides it home. Mr. Miyasako creates an incisive portrait of a sleazy charmer who can talk his way out of any situation. When one creditor comes banging on the door, Shuji flashesa wad of bills and pays him off. But that creditor is only one of many. And where did that money come from? The local news is carrying the story of a series of robberies of funeral offerings, including one at the very mortuary that oversaw the grandfather's funeral.
Tomoko's alienation is embodied in the fable that gives the movie its title. She recalls as a girl hearing her brother boast about discovering a remote patch of wild berries deep in a forest not too far from their home. But when she went looking for the fruit she couldn't find it and got lost. When she reminds Shuji of the incident, he offers to show her the patch. What happens during their hike into the woods encapsulates the dangerous moral quagmire Tomoko finds herself so desperate to flee.

WILD BERRIES

Written and directed by Miwa Nishikawa; in Japanese, with English subtitles; director of photography, Hideo Yamamoto; edited by Ryuji Miyajima; music by Masaru Nakamura; production designer, Toshihiro Isomi; produced by Hirokazu Kore-Eda. Running time: 108 minutes. This film is not rated. Shown with a 10-minute short, Michael Baig Clifford's "Bouncer," tonight at 9 at the Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, and tomorrow night at 6 at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center as part of the 32nd New Directors/New Films series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film and media of the Museum of Modern Art.

WITH: Hiroyuki Miyasako (Shuji), Miho Tsumiki (Tomoko), Sei Hiraizumi (Yoshiro), Naoko Otani (Akiko), Toru Tezuka (Kensaku Kamata), Moeko Ezawa (Kimiko), Susumu Terajima (Maeda) and Matsunosuke Shofukutei (Kyozo).

PERSON: Alfred Eisenpreis 

HEADLINE: Alfred Eisenpreis, 78, City Administrator 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Alfred Eisenpreis, New York City's economic development administrator for two and a half years in the mid-1970's, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on Thursday. He was 78 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
 The cause was not immediately disclosed, but he had been suffering from lymphoma. 
 Dr. Eisenpreis was a vice president for marketing with the Allied Stores Corporation, a nationwide chain, when Mayor Abraham D. Beame appointed him to head the city's Economic Development Administration in January 1974.
Mr. Beame said at the time that the appointment was "an important part of a message I wish to convey to the business community," and "I want business to know that this is a city where business interest and public interest can be brought together for everyone's benefit."
Dr. Eisenpreis, whose doctorate was in public policy from Union Institute, was also a member of the National Council for Urban Economic Development in 1975 and 1976.
He resigned as economic development administrator in June 1976, while Mr. Beame went ahead with plans to revamp his administration's efforts to assist the city's drooping economy.
Mr. Beame said at the time that he had not requested Dr. Eisenpreis's resignation. But other mayoral aides indicated that he had grown disappointed both with Dr. Eisenpreis's work as administrator and with City Hall's entire unsuccessful drive to halt the city's job losses, which by then totaled 645,100 from 1969.
Over the years Dr. Eisenpreis held many posts in business and other fields. He was a member of the board and treasurer of Congregation Emanu-El of New York City.
Born in Vienna, he moved to the United States in 1939. He received a bachelor's degree from St. Thomas College in Scranton, Pa., and master's degrees in political science, management and human resources from the New York School of Social Research. His marriage to Bettijane Long Eisenpreis ended in divorce.
He is survived by his companion, Joan C. Schwartz; and his son, Steven, both of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: A Deadly Virus on Its Mind, Hong Kong Covers Its Face 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 30 

 BODY:
It is beginning to feel a lot like Halloween here, with more and more people wearing masks and the health news getting scarier by the day.
 Health officials here announced 60 more cases today of a mysterious pneumonia known as severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. The additional cases bring the total for the last four days to 204 -- more than in the rest of the world combined, not counting mainland China, which has not yet reported any cases in March. 
 The State Department warned over the weekend that the quality of medical services here and in Hanoi, Vietnam, was being affected by the pressure on hospitals of treating the illness. 
Singapore said today that nurses would meet flights from here and other affected cities to assess the health of passengers, while Thailand said it would quarantine, for 24 hours, anyone who arrived from here and showed any sign of being unwell. In Canada, a fourth person died today, linked to a previous death in the same Toronto area hospital. 
When an employee falls ill with the infectious disease, companies like HSBC and Hewlett-Packard temporarily close offices for disinfection and send other workers home. Economists warn of serious damage to the local economy, which depends on tourism and particularly on its place as a base for businesses with operations across Asia.
Some expatriates and affluent citizens are beginning to flee the city, taking home leave or extended vacations. But for those who stay, the common surgical mask has become a subject of obsessive interest.
For starters, there are the practical difficulties, as people who have never worn the masks try to figure out how to tie knots on top of their heads and behind their necks. "It is very suffocating and hot, and it is inconvenient, as I have to take it off before eating and put it on after eating," said John Fung, a 30-year-old researcher.
Wearing a mask can also make everyday tasks more difficult, especially when it is poorly adjusted. "It is very inconvenient when talking with people," because a mask can muffle sound, complained Ho Sau Ying, a 52-year-old delivery clerk. "When I drink water, I have to take it off, and it is not good for seeing."
Isabella Kau, a popular author and commentator on etiquette in this status-conscious city, declared that there was no socially acceptable way to wear a face mask. But, she added, "in today's circumstances, I do not think it is embarrassing to wear a face mask in public."
Markups on masks are sometimes steep. While basic green or white surgical masks remain the most common, they are coming in a growing array of colors, as well as with cartoon images, including Hello Kitty and characters from "101 Dalmatians." Some show the United States flag, still identified here to some extent with democratic values and the students who were massacred at Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989.
To wear a mask at all has become something of a political statement. Pro-democracy lawmakers have been pushing the government to ask everyone to wear them; initially, they saw the masks as an alternative to government quarantines and what they consider other infringements on the civil liberties of patients and their families, although hostility to quarantines has faded as the spread of the disease has accelerated.
Government officials have resisted wearing masks, while trying to reassure businesses and tourists that Hong Kong is not a dangerous place to work or to visit.
Doctors say sick people who put on masks become less likely to transmit the illness when they cough or sneeze. But it is unclear whether the masks help the healthy. They quickly become saturated with moisture from breath and lose some usefulness when worn for hours -- much less for days, as is happening here now -- local doctors warn.
Many people here tie the masks so loosely that air flows around the edges instead of being filtered by the fabric. The virus responsible for the respiratory syndrome also appears to be transmitted like common cold viruses by people who touch a contaminated surface and then touch their eyes, nose or mouth.
The World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Hong Kong Health Department have all said masks are mainly of value for health care workers, to help prevent the spread of illness by people who feel sick and to protect those in close contact with those who feel ill. Advocates of wider mask use contend that people who are starting to feel unwell, and are thus perhaps on the verge of infectiousness, are more likely to wear masks if they are less likely to be stigmatized in a community where healthy people are wearing masks too.
Hong Kong has had 530 cases so far among its seven million people, so healthy people with no close contacts with ill ones may not need to worry too much yet, unless the spread of the disease continues to accelerate. 
"In my head, I know that it's not a big deal," said Alfie Wong, who wore a mask on Saturday afternoon. "But in my heart, I'm frightened."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Face masks have become an obsession in Hong Kong as the mysterious pneumonia known as severe acute respiratory syndrome spreads. (Michael Caronna for The New York Times)

PERSON: Robert E. Hudec 

HEADLINE: Robert E. Hudec, 68, Expert on Global Trade Law, Dies 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
Robert E. Hudec, a professor who broadened the study of laws governing international trade to embrace matters of diplomacy and politics, died on March 12 while vacationing in North Captiva Island, Fla. He was 68.
 The cause was coronary heart disease, according to an announcement by Tufts University, where Professor Hudec had taught since 2000. He lived in Newton, Mass. 
 Along with John H. Jackson, who directs the Institute of International Economic Law at Georgetown University, Professor Hudec "was simply one of the founders of international trade law as a discipline that was a subject of scholarly research and teaching at major universities," said Robert L. Howse, a law professor at the University of Michigan.
"He developed an approach that neither reduced international trade law to economic policy nor made the law into a kind of formal structure impermeable to politics and diplomacy," Professor Howse said. "He gave both legalism and diplomacy their due."
According to Professor Hudec's philosophy, a legal institution governing international trade would have to be sensitive to political and diplomatic considerations -- even allowing them to supersede its authority in some circumstances -- to avoid becoming so inflexible as to render itself harmful or irrelevant.
This belief, combined with his legal expertise, led Professor Hudec to become a participant in, and critic of, the dispute-settlement processes of the World Trade Organization and its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Robert Emil Hudec was born in Cleveland and raised nearby in North Olmsted, Ohio. Though his parents, who had immigrated from Slovakia, were unsure of the value of a college education, a high school guidance counselor persuaded him to apply. He was accepted at Kenyon College, where he met Marianne Miller, a student at nearby Denison College, on a blind date. They were married in 1956.
Professor Hudec began as a chemistry major but broke so much glassware in the laboratory that he could not afford to continue. He graduated summa cum laude in political science and moved to England, were he studied at Cambridge University as a Marshall Scholar.
After serving as editor in chief of the Yale Law Journal while earning a law degree, he became a clerk for Justice Potter Stewart of the United States Supreme Court from 1961 to 1963.
After a short stint at the predecessor of the United States trade representative's office and several years as a professor at Yale, Mr. Hudec taught law for 28 years at the University of Minnesota and then joined Tufts. 
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Katharine Wright Hudec, of West Newton, Mass.; a son, Michael Robert, of Austin, Tex.; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Foundations' 2002 Giving Held Steady, Report Finds 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Neither volatile stock market nor weak economy nor bad investments made much of a dent in giving by foundations last year.
 Grants from the nation's more than 62,000 foundations in 2002 totaled $30.3 billion, basically keeping pace with those in the previous year, according to a survey to be released today by the Foundation Center, a research organization in New York. 
 But foundation executives and experts on philanthropy are bracing themselves for a decline next year, although no one was willing to guess how sharp reductions would be. Foundation giving did fall by 0.7 percent, a number that was statistically negligible but still the first decrease since 1983, after six consecutive years of double-digit growth. 
"We're in a different time right now," said Loren Renz, vice president for research at the Foundation Center. "I don't think it came as fast as people expected or feared, but now we're at the point where foundations are faced with a real dilemma: how to balance the desire to preserve assets with the responsibility to maintain the viability of the nonprofits you support."
Jon Small, president of the Nonprofit Coordinating Committee of New York, a trade group representing more than 1,100 organizations, said nonprofit organizations were still trying to assess how big the hits would be.
"My sense is that for the most part, foundations are sticking with the organizations and programs they know and love, so it's very hard for a new face or program to find funding," Mr. Small said.
Giving has been stable so far largely because many foundations, particularly the largest ones, determine their spending based on a three-year average of their asset values. Thus, while asset values have dropped, in some cases markedly, the average reflects one or two years when assets were buoyed by robust stock prices.
Those better years, however, are beginning to fall out of the mix.
The Robert R. McCormick Tribune Foundation's assets, which are almost entirely Tribune Company stock, peaked at almost $2 billion in 1999, and that figure was included in the average used last year to determine giving.
This year, the 1999 figure fell out of the average and was replaced by the value of the foundation's 2002 assets, $1.8 billion, reducing the average used to determine gifts by 3.6 percent, so the foundation's giving will fall by roughly 4 percent this year, said Louis I. Marsico, its treasurer.
Only 6 of the 50 largest foundations had gains in their assets in 2001, the latest year for which data is available. Only two of those, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation and the Moody Foundation, gained 10 percent or more -- and the Hewlett Foundation's increase was solely attributable to a $3.1 billion bequest. 
In contrast, the assets of 29 percent of those foundations fell 10 percent or more, and five foundations -- the Ford Foundation, the Lilly Endowment, the J. Paul Getty Trust, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation and the Starr Foundation -- lost more than $1 billion each.
Asset values continued to fall last year, although most experts say the biggest declines occurred in 2001. For instance, the Annie E. Casey Foundation's asset value remained relatively stable last year at $2.7 billion after falling 13.6 percent in 2001.
Doug Nelson, president of the Casey Foundation, said it had moved quickly to diversify its asset base, which is still largely tied up in United Parcel Service stock, and change its investment managers. 
The Casey Foundation is among those that say they are committed to maintaining their spending levels despite fluctuations in asset values. It plans to spend $186 million this year, or about 7 percent of its assets, almost exactly what it spent last year.
That is higher than the 5 percent foundations must spend to maintain their tax exemption, but Casey is one of a growing number of foundations spending more than required.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: YANKEES NOTEBOOK; 
Matsui And Mates Bracing For Boos

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 30 

 BODY:
Late in spring training, Hideki Matsui enjoyed a rare moment alone in the visitors' clubhouse in St. Petersburg, Fla. As the final innings of a game played out on the field, Matsui studied a Japanese book about major league ballparks. He lingered on the Skydome page for several minutes.
 It is finally happening for Matsui, the Yankees' $21 million free-agent prize. He will begin his American major league career at the Skydome on Monday, batting fifth and playing left field. If Matsui thought the Blue Jays welcomed him rudely today, he was not saying. 
Taped to the door of the Yankees' clubhouse was a team-sponsored newspaper ad that targeted Matsui. "Boo Matsui," it read, in English and Japanese, with a photo of a Yankee cap pelted by bird droppings. The ad offended Yankees Manager Joe Torre, but Matsui was restrained.
"I don't have anything special to say," he said through an interpreter. "I guess I'm happy that the fans are actually aware of my name."
Torre saw the ad while riding the team bus this morning. He believed it was inappropriate and said it went "beyond having fun."
"I thought it was tasteless, especially in the climate of what's going on in the world," Torre said. "I can understand fun and games, but I thought it was a little bit too much."
The Blue Jays did not even scout Matsui in Japan, knowing that teams like the Yankees could outbid them by millions. Toronto's director for corporate marketing, Jim Bloom, devised the ad as a way to tweak the Yankees.
"We don't mean any disrespect to Matsui," Bloom said. "It was a high-profile, high-priced signing. We are a team trying to live within the constraints of current baseball economics. It's just done with a sense of humor."
The Blue Jays are trying to revive sagging fan interest, and they will give away Eric Hinske bobblehead dolls as further enticement for Monday's game. The team's president, Paul Godfrey, said more than 40,000 tickets had been sold.
Godfrey said he hoped fans would be respectful when "God Bless America" is sung during the seventh-inning stretch. Fans in some Canadian arenas have booed the American national anthem.
"As far as I'm concerned, you never go wrong by paying respect," Godfrey said.
"If there are fools and idiots who stand up and boo, they're silly. We have American players playing for us, and our guests in town are Americans, the New York Yankees. People should stand up and honor that."
As for Matsui, he will get used to booing, several teammates said. Matsui said Japanese fans rarely boo.
"I don't think everybody who comes out is going to boo Matsui," first baseman Jason Giambi said. "They're going to boo the Yankees, period."

No Surprises in Lineup
Against Toronto's Roy Halladay on Monday, Joe Torre will use the same lineup he used late in spring training.
Alfonso Soriano will lead off, followed by Derek Jeter, Jason Giambi, Bernie Williams, Hideki Matsui, Jorge Posada, Robin Ventura, Raul Mondesi and designated hitter Nick Johnson.

Trainers Warn Yankees
Team trainers told Yankees players to take precautions against severe acute respiratory syndrome, known as SARS, which has caused two Toronto-area hospitals to close and thousands of people to be quarantined. Players were given information explaining SARS, which has resulted in deaths around the world, and told to stay away from hospitals.
"It's scary, no question about it," Joe Torre said. "But I haven't sensed a whole lot of worry about it."

Latham Makes Team
As the Yankees' reserve center fielder, Chris Latham has made an opening day roster for the first time since 1999, when he played for Minnesota. Latham played for the Blue Jays in 2001 and was let go on waivers last March. He spent last season with the Mets' Class AAA Norfolk team, had elbow surgery in the winter and signed with the Yankees.
"To not be able to make a team like Toronto and to come over here and make a team like the Yankees, it's been a blessing," Latham said.
The Yankees will use Latham mainly as a pinch-runner.

HEADLINE: Union Drive at Montefiore Could Be Labor Landmark 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
For a decade, New York hospitals have talked about the need to be more efficient -- to trim staff, attract patients, invest in technology and find less costly ways of delivering care.
 At many places, it has been little more than talk. But Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx has pulled it off, becoming one of the most financially successful hospitals in the city, a model that other hospitals look to. 
 Now, that very success lies at the heart of a labor dispute that could have repercussions far beyond the hospital walls. Many residents and interns, the hospital's doctors-in-training, say the pressure to do more with less is compromising their medical education and patient care, and they are trying to unionize, still an extreme rarity in American hospitals. 
Officials at Montefiore dispute the complaints, and unlike the handful of other hospitals around the city where doctors have organized in recent years, Montefiore is waging an aggressive campaign against the union drive. The hospital has taken several steps to delay or defeat a possible unionization vote and, more important, it is asking a federal government agency to rule that residents and interns do not have the standard rights of an employee group to unionize.
To the union, the Committee of Interns and Residents, Montefiore represents an enormous opportunity. It is one of the largest hospitals in the city, with more than 1,000 beds, and if the union wins, Montefiore's will be the largest corps of unionized doctors anywhere in the country. Union leaders hope that if Montefiore, after putting up a fierce fight, fails to stop them, then other hospitals, at least those in the city, will fall like dominoes.
In short, Montefiore, already a trend-setter, is seen by both sides in this dispute as setting precedents -- perhaps national ones -- in labor relations.
Unlike many labor disputes, this one is not about wages. (Montefiore pays interns and residents $43,000 to more than $50,000 per year, according to the hospital, similar to the scales at other premier teaching hospitals.) Rather, the doctors' main complaint is that staff cuts have forced them to perform chores that used to be done by less-skilled workers, at Montefiore's main campus in Bedford Park, in the northwest Bronx, and at the campus in Morris Park in the east Bronx, adjacent to the affiliated Albert Einstein College of Medicine.
"To have to answer the phones, to have to draw the bloods, to have to wheel the patients to X-ray ourselves, that is not the best use of our time and our resources," said Dr. Stephen Cha, a third-year resident in internal medicine. "That's time not spent on patient care."
The union contends that even as the number of patients treated has climbed rapidly, Montefiore has reduced its work force within the hospital by about 5 percent over the last five years. Hospital officials say that is an exaggeration, while acknowledging some reduction.
Some doctors say that attending physicians -- the doctors who have graduated from their residencies and are employed by the hospital -- have been forced to spend more time on patient care and less on teaching interns and residents.
To the complaints of the doctors, also known as house officers, Montefiore's president, Dr. Spencer Foreman, said, "It was ever thus, and it will ever thus be."
"The house officers' notion of the way it should be is there should be a team of four people standing beside them," he said. "It would be wonderful but you couldn't keep the doors open. So everyone works like hell."
Even so, he said, the hospital has listened to their complaints and has worked hard to respond. And he said the hospital has specialists with double board certification on duty -- not on call, but on duty -- around the clock in each of its critical care units, a rare and expensive investment in quality care.
The central figure in this fight is Dr. Foreman, universally known as Spike, the hospital's leader since 1986, and a suave, canny administrator who is viewed by his staff as a figure of both admiration and intimidation. He is one of the city's longest-serving hospital chiefs, and one of the best paid, at more than $1.5 million a year in salary and other forms of compensation.
No one disputes that he has taken a hospital that was near bankruptcy and turned it into a success story. Under him, revenues have doubled, admissions have nearly doubled, and the hospital has invested $1 billion in capital improvements and added one million square feet of space, including a new Children's Hospital loaded with such eye-catching extras as outer space-themed decor, plasma-screen televisions and Internet connections in each room. In 2001, Montefiore reported clearing $12.7 million on $1.2 billion in revenue -- a 1 percent margin that would be considered meager in most businesses, but qualifies as robust in the troubled world of New York City hospitals.
Other hospitals in the city tried to economize by merging in the 1990's, and often regretted it. Dr. Foreman resisted the trend. In an era when the city's hospitals have tried to save by shifting primary care out of their main buildings and into community clinics, Montefiore's is one of the few clinic networks not considered a money-loser.
Montefiore was an early convert to hospital marketing, holding itself out as a leader in pediatrics, women's health and cancer care, and it has succeeded in drawing large numbers of patients from the more affluent Westchester County, improving its bottom line. Montefiore has also invested heavily in high technology, becoming one of the first hospitals in the country to adopt a paperless system for tracking all doctors' orders, like prescriptions and blood tests -- a practice that advocates say reduces medical errors.
But conversations with doctors reveal a widespread unease. "It's a great hospital and they've done some great things," said Rob Darzynkiewicz, a fourth-year resident in emergency medicine. "But we've got residents changing bedpans, which prevents us from seeing more patients. The doctor is ultimately responsible, medically and legally. We aren't going to allow these chores not to get done, even if that means doing them ourselves."
The idea of a union remains alien to most doctors and hospitals. Attending physicians around the country have long had the right to organize, but they rarely do.
But until recently, the National Labor Relations Board viewed interns and residents as students more than employees. As a result, they did not have the rights that federal law grants almost all worker groups: to unionize by a majority vote, in an election overseen by the board, with management obliged to recognize and bargain with the resulting union. Residents' and interns' only real leverage to force management's recognition was to strike, an almost unheard-of step.
Then, in 1999, in a case involving Boston Medical Center, the labor board overturned its longstanding policy, and ruled that residents and interns were entitled to the same protections as other employee groups. Since then, those doctors have unionized at only about a dozen hospitals around the country, half of them in New York City, according to the Committee of Interns and Residents, an arm of the Service Employees International Union.
Montefiore has become the first hospital in the country to challenge that 1999 decision, asking the labor board to reverse itself again -- a position that could delay any union vote until most of the residents who began the drive last year are gone. The hospital's request is the subject of a hearing that has been under way at the board's regional office since October. Whatever the outcome, it will probably be appealed to the board, itself, in Washington.
"The house staff represent a class of person who are indistinguishable from any other class of students," Dr. Foreman said. "The union-management interface is not the appropriate one in an educational setting. I think the Boston decision was wrong."
Under the Boston ruling, residents and interns at each hospital are lumped into a single bargaining unit with attending physicians, unless both union and management agree to treat them separately. Other New York City hospitals that have seen union drives have agreed to divide the two groups.
But Montefiore has insisted that any vote, if it comes, must include all the doctors -- a position that will make it much harder for the union to win such a vote. Montefiore is one of the few teaching hospitals where the hospital, and not the medical school, employs the attending physicians. That means that at Montefiore, unlike most hospitals, attending physicians outnumber residents and interns, by about 1,200 to 800.
While an overwhelming majority of residents and interns signed a petition last year seeking a union vote, a fairly small minority of attending doctors signed. In interviews, attending doctors were less likely than residents and interns to be sharply critical of the hospital -- and much less likely to allow their names to be used.
Doctors say that since the unionization drive began, the hospital has, as one put it, "thrown candy at us," in an attempt to win them over. In the last year, residents and interns have received a $500 textbook allowance, new health benefits and parking privileges and free meals in the hospital cafeterias, and they have been promised a raise in July.
"They're obviously taking this organizing drive very seriously, as are we," said Michael Phelan, organizing director of the Committee of Interns and Residents. "This one could be a watershed for us and the industry."
Montefiore has a long record of milestone labor relations. Decades ago, it was one of the first hospitals in the city to recognize and bargain with 1199,the union for most hospital workers, and the Committee of Interns and Residents -- well before the law required that they acknowledge the unions.
Then, in 1981, residents and interns struck seven municipal hospitals, defying a court order. In solidarity, they struck Montefiore, too, enraging its administration. Montefiore rescinded its recognition of the Committee, and 22 years later, the union still has not regained that status.
