HEADLINE: In Albany, the Only Surplus Is of Plans to Increase Taxes 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER

 BODY:
Last week, New York's legislative leaders reached a deal on how to borrow $4.2 billion to help solve the state's budget mess, the worst since the Depression.
 The next decisions the Legislature must make to reach a budget consensus are, however, the toughest of all: What to cut. What to keep. And how to pay for it. 
 Lobbyists have been descending on the Capitol in Albany, trying to influence the thinking of lawmakers on what is essential and what is expendable. Busloads of teachers, students, health care workers and nursing home employees show up -- especially on Tuesdays -- to plead their cases. It is a ritual known as tin cup Tuesday. Tomorrow, the state's largest health care union is planning a demonstration at the Capitol, and have rented buses from as far as Ohio to help transport its members.
The special interest groups are lobbying for changes to Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for closing a $11.5 billion deficit through a combination of borrowing, budget cuts and $1.4 billion in tax increases, higher fees, fines and other revenues.
Legislative leaders have criticized the governor's $90.8 billion budget for its cuts to education and health care. Further, Democratic lawmakers and others say, raising college tuition and cutting student aid amount to tax increases.
So a variety of tax-increase plans are being floated around the Capitol, on the theory that a Legislature reluctant to raise taxes would be even more phobic about cutting core services to constituents.
"The only thing that is an even greater unspoken fact than the willingness of many of these guys to do a tax increase is their unwillingness to even think about other kinds of spending cuts," said E. J. McMahon, a fiscal analyst with the conservative Manhattan Institute and a former legislative budget director in Albany.
Among the new kinds of tax proposals are a few that aim to close corporate tax loopholes; some that would place a temporary personal income tax surcharge on the wealthiest New Yorkers; a revival of a tax on stock trades, and a tax on businesses that do not provide insurance coverage for their employees, a sort of penalty tax dedicated to a pool of money that compensates hospitals for charity care.
A coalition known as New Yorkers for Fiscal Fairness and Dennis Rivera, the powerful leader of the health care workers' union, 1199/S.E.I.U., say closing some corporate tax shelters would raise about $1.5 billion. One idea is to tax companies on the combined income from their subsidiaries, including those in states where income tax is not collected. Another is for a minimum tax on companies' gross receipts, or sales, rather than on profits, to garner $400 million to $460 million. New Jersey did that last year, calling it the alternative minimum tax.
To raise what advocates an estimated $545 million, the state could reverse its decision last year allowing companies to write off capital investments on an accelerated schedule. 
The unions have also floated the idea of increasing, by seven-tenths of 1 percent, the tax rate for people earning more than $100,000, and to institute a 1.4 percent tax increase for people making more than $200,000. That would bring in about $3 billion, the unions say.
Dan Cantor, executive director of the Working Families Party, advocates a revival of the stock transfer tax, which had existed in New York for 70 years before it was suspended in 1981. It would tax the buying or selling of shares on the New York Stock Exchange or the American Stock Exchange, but not Nasdaq.
The tax, ranging from a penny to a nickel depending on the cost of a share, would produce about $7.6 billion in one year, said Mr. Cantor, citing statistics from the State Department of Taxation, which he said collects the tax and instantly gives it back. Mr. Cantor said the tax could be capped at a lower amount than it had been capped before -- at $175 per transaction compared with $350 per transaction before it was suspended. 
The state's biggest gap-closing revenue proposal involves borrowing about $4.2 billion against future income from a settlement with tobacco companies. That deal, reached by the Legislature last week, has so troubled Elizabeth A. Lynam, director of state studies for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group, that she has called for temporary broad- based surcharge on personal income taxes.
The surcharge would start at 15 percent and decline each year until it ended after three years, provided that state spending could be cut to match revenues and that the state reformed its budget process.
"We reluctantly support a tax increase," Ms. Lynam said. "But to us, that's preferable to borrowing, which asks future New Yorkers to pay for services today."
Business leaders are already lining up against the tax proposals. Many say closing corporate tax loopholes is just another way of rescinding tax benefits created to help businesses. They argue that adopting the options floated so far would harm the state's overall economic health.
It is an argument that Governor Pataki has often made. His budget proposal resisted raising broad-based taxes, concentrating instead on smaller tax increases.
The business community says that a disproportionate share of the state's tax burden falls on them. 
"Business pays its fair share, if not more," said Robert B. Ward, director of research at the Business Council of New York State. "It pays one of every four dollars in taxes at the state level."
He said the state collects about $1.8 billion in corporate income taxes compared with $24 billion in personal income taxes, so that squeezing revenue from the corporate side would require huge percentage increases that would hurt businesses.
"At some point, the recession is going to end," Mr. Ward said. "When that happens, there's going to be a rush toward investment, and we want that investment to happen in New York as much as possible."
He and others say that lavish spending is partly to blame for the current crisis. If spending of state funds had kept pace with inflation over the past five years, instead of significantly outpacing it, this year's deficit would be $7.9 billion lower, Mr. Ward said.
For that reason, Mr. McMahon, of the Manhattan Institute, is calling for a package of eight spending reductions that he says would save $1 billion next year, and more in the future. They include reducing the state payroll beyond what Mr. Pataki has proposed, reining in health care costs, eliminating rent regulations and repealing the state Wicks Law, which requires most public building construction projects to use different contractors for different types of work. 
"Putting a big tax increase on the table in front of the New York State Legislature and calling it temporary," Mr. McMahon said, "is like driving a truckload of pure uncut heroin into a neighborhood of junkies and calling it a temporary fix."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: AGAINST THE GRAIN; 
Bonds Treats Age Like Bad Pitch

BYLINE:  By ALLEN BARRA 

 BODY:
From 1990 to 1999, Barry Bonds was arguably the best player in baseball. For the decade, Bonds hit .302 and averaged 36 home runs and 115 walks a season. In the two most important hitting categories, he led the National League in on-base percentage four times and slugging percentage three times. 
 By 1999, at the age of 35, Bonds seemed to be on the downside of a Hall of Fame career, hitting only .262 with 219 total bases, his worst numbers since his rookie year in 1986. In the 2000 season, though, Bonds increased his home run total by 15 (34 to 49), his batting average 44 points (.262 to .306), his on-base percentage 51 points (.389 to .440) and his slugging percentage a whopping 71 points (.617 to .688). 
 Not many players get significantly better after the age of 35, but that was just the beginning. In 2001, the 37-year-old Barry Bonds was no longer competing with the young Barry Bonds: he was competing with the young Babe Ruth. That year, Bonds set a major league record for home runs (73) and slugging percentage (.863). From 35 through 37, when most players are contemplating retirement, he more than doubled his home run total. 
Because Bonds hit 27 fewer home runs in 2002 than in 2001, it wasn't obvious to many that he was an even more effective hitter. He won his first National League batting title at .370 (the oldest player in league history to win a batting crown) and set major league records for walks (198) and on-base percentage (.582). He struck out only 47 times in 143 games, posting the lowest ratio of strikeouts per at-bats in his career. By some yardsticks, it may have been the greatest performance by a National League hitter. 
Some baseball analysts like to add on-base and slugging percentages as a quick measure of all-around batting effectiveness. George Ignatin, a professor of economics and a sports statistician at the University of Alabama-Birmingham, argues that multiplying on-base and slugging gives a more accurate assessment of a hitter's run-producing potential. Ignatin refers to the statistic as SLOB. Bonds's 2002 SLOB of .465 means that Bonds created 46.5 runs per 100 at-bats, topping even his 2001 mark of .444. Let's put that in perspective: in 1921, Babe Ruth posted a .433 SLOB, the highest of his career. 
If Bonds had had seasons like his last two when he was 25 and 26, it would have been remarkable enough. That he has done so at 37 and 38 practically puts him in a league of his own, not only in baseball but also in sports history. Michael Jordan was a great player when he came out of retirement at age 38 in 2001, but no one said that he was the best player in basketball or that he was better than he had been at his peak 10 years earlier. George Foreman was 45 when he won one of the numerous heavyweight championship belts in 1994, but no one claimed that he was better on that night than when he beat Joe Frazier for the undisputed heavyweight title in 1973. 
N.F.L. history suggests one example of a Bonds-like performance. In 1962, at age 36, Y. A. Tittle threw 33 touchdown passes in 14 games for the Giants, then topped that with 36 in 13 games in '63. (Tittle's previous high was 20 touchdown passes in 1953.) A large part of Tittle's success, though, was his going to a much better team in New York than the one he had left in San Francisco.
The reasons offered for Barry Bonds's amazing late-career resurgence have ranged from steroid use (which Bonds vehemently denies) to laser eye surgery (for which no evidence has yet been found) to his maple whip-handled bats to his famous body armor (said by some to mysteriously supercharge his reflexes). The problem with all these theories is that they don't explain why Bonds's level of performance has been so much higher than that of his younger contemporaries, who have had access to the same advantages. Meanwhile, Barry Bonds finds himself in the unique position of a 39-year-old who, if he bats .300 with 40 home runs, will hear talk that he is slipping.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Since he turned 35 in 1999, the Giants' Barry Bonds has become even more dangerous at the plate. (Deanne Fitzmaurice/San Francisco Chronicle)

HEADLINE: Police Arrest Brooklyn Man In Slayings of 4 Shopkeepers 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH

 BODY:
The police have arrested a Brooklyn man who they believe has shot and killed four shopkeepers without provocation in Brooklyn and Queens since early last month, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced last night.
 The suspect, Larme Price, 30, confessed on Saturday to the four slayings, which terrorized residents and small-business owners and had been described as the work of a serial killer, the police said. Mr. Price said he was motivated by a desire to kill people of Middle Eastern descent after the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Mr. Kelly said at a news conference at police headquarters. 
 Only one of the four victims, all foreign-born men, was from the Middle East, but Mr. Price was apparently under the impression that they all were, Mr. Kelly said.
Mr. Price, the police say, shot the four victims in the head, usually without demanding money. He will be prosecuted first by the district attorney's office in Brooklyn, where three of the killings took place, Mr. Kelly said. A law enforcement official said charges would include multiple counts of first-degree murder, a crime that could be punishable by death. He will also face two counts of attempted murder, Mr. Kelly said.
Mr. Price drew attention to himself when he walked into the 77th Precinct station house on Friday night and offered to help the police find the killer, Mr. Kelly said. 
Mr. Price told investigators the killer went by the nickname "Dog" and "appeared eager to help the investigation," Mr. Kelly noted. The investigators quickly became suspicious of Mr. Price, whose walk and appearance, they say, resembled that of the killer. They did not have enough evidence to detain him. But the next day, speaking to investigators on a cellphone, Mr. Price broke down and confessed to the killings, Mr. Kelly said.
Mr. Price said he was confessing because he had been reading the Bible, particularly the commandment "Thou shalt not kill," Mr. Kelly said, and because he was concerned about his two daughters. 
The police said Mr. Price did not appear to have been involved in a fifth fatal shooting that took place at an auto parts store in East New York, Brooklyn, on March 1. Members of the task force assigned to the case had believed that killing was carried out by the same man.
Mr. Price told the police that he killed one of his victims, a Russian-born man who worked at an all-night coin laundry in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, because Mr. Price felt disrespected when the man told him he could not sit in the store unless he was doing laundry there, Mr. Kelly said. 
Asked about Mr. Price's statement that he wanted to kill people of Middle Eastern descent, Mr. Kelly said, "I believe it fits the definition of a bias crime." 
But Mr. Price's mother, Leatha Price, said yesterday that her son's anger at Middle Easterners was a matter of mental illness, not ethnic hatred.
Speaking at the door of her apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Ms. Price said her son had a history of drug abuse and mental health problems, and that as recently as three weeks ago she had tried unsuccessfully to have him admitted to Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn because he appeared to be mentally unbalanced. She said her son ranted wildly, claiming that the Central Intelligence Agency was after him and that the hospital had put a tracking device in his hand. 
After the Sept. 11 attacks, "he walked around scared all the time, he couldn't sit still," Ms. Price said. At one point he said, "I'm going to join the war," she added. After themost recent trip to the hospital, he was scared to come out of the car, saying, " 'They're following me, Ma, they're following me,' " she said.
"We kept trying to get help for him, but they kept letting him go," Ms. Price said. 
The police are investigating the possibility that Mr. Price is mentally ill, Mr. Kelly said.
The police have also detained a man who was with Mr. Price during the first killing, at a food market in Ozone Park, Queens, on Feb. 8, Mr. Kelly said. That man, whose name was not released, is being considered a witness. Mr. Price was alone during all the other shootings.
In addition to Mr. Price's confession, there is ample evidence linking Mr. Price to all four killings, Mr. Kelly said. Investigators have recovered the 9-millimeter Intertech handgun that they say was used in the most recent killing, on March 20, at the Stop I Food Market in Crown Heights. They said they had also found a distinctive hat, gloves and other clothing that could be seen on surveillance videotape taken at the scenes of other killings.
The gun and clothing were found at the home of Mr. Price's girlfriend, who is pregnant with his child, Mr. Kelly said. She is not the mother of Mr. Price's two other children, who have different mothers, Mr. Kelly added.
Mr. Price discarded the .40-caliber handgun he used in the first three killings because he was out of ammunition and knew that the police were looking for it, Mr. Kelly said. That gun has not been recovered.
Mr. Price, who is unemployed, has eight prior arrests dating back to 1989, on charges including robbery, assault, burglary and criminal possession of a weapon, Mr. Kelly said. In the past, he has sold textbooks, which the police believe were stolen, on the street near the campuses of New York City colleges, Mr. Kelly said. 
Mr. Price lives at 1225 Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights, Mr. Kelly said. The building is less than a block from the Stop I Food Market, where a Yemeni immigrant was shot and killed on March 20. Several residents in the building said yesterday that Mr. Price had often shopped there. 
After that shooting, the police say, Mr. Price also shot Yakoob Aldailam, 21, an employee at the market, three times, seriously wounding him. Like many others in the neighborhood, Mr. Aldailam, who is still recovering at the Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, was relieved to hear the news that someone had confessed in the string of deadly shootings, his family said.
"Before, when I went to see my nephew, he would tell me, 'Hold my hand, stay with me,' " said Adel Aldailam, Mr. Aldailam's uncle, whose family owns the Stop I Food Market. "But now my nephew is very happy. He is relieved a lot. Now he is going to be O.K."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larme Price, 30, in custody yesterday after his arrest in a string of shootings. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE HOME FRONT; 
Rallying Round Those the Reserves Left Behind

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: DRESDEN, Tenn., March 27 

 BODY:
Sgt. Don Winstead of the 1174th Transportation Company of the Tennessee National Guard is a self-employed logger who carries big loans on his trucks and tree-cutting machinery. On active duty since late January, he has been stuck 80 miles away at Fort Campbell, Ky., and expects to be shipped to Kuwait any day. He has taken a big cut in his income, to $2,300 a month, so he cannot keep up his payments.
 As required by law for mobilized soldiers, his banks lowered interest rates to 6 percent, in Sergeant Winstead's case from 7 and 8 percent. But Bobby German, president of the Dresden branch of First State Bank, went further. He postponed all payments on the principal for a year, for now the duration of Sergeant Winstead's active duty, so the sergeant pays only the interest. 
 "They said: 'If you can't make that, don't worry about it. We'll work it out,' " Sergeant Winstead said. 
Dresden, in West Tennessee, population 2,800, seat of Weakley County, population 35,000, is one of those thousands of places that are home to members of the Reserves and National Guard. They are men and women, some in their 40's, teachers and social workers and business owners and retail clerks, who have been taken away for war in Iraq. This week, the Pentagon said 216,811 members of the National Guard and the Reserves had been activated, 150,071 of them by the Army.
To help, the people of Weakley County are going beyond letters, cards and prayers for troops who were once lightly called weekend warriors. "No one's place will go up on the auction block for failure to pay property taxes," Don Gifford, the county executive, said. 
 Dresden's mayor, Danny Forrester, said that if the 1174th's families, deprived of their breadwinners, fall behind on the waterand sewer bill, the city will postpone or forgive it. If they need a handyman, he will send somebody out. "The soldiers do not have to worry about their families," Mr. Forrester said. "We'll do everything to look after them." 
 As customers finish their business here, the clerks in the courthouse, florists and bankers say, "Come back." If as old and automatic as tying a shoe, there is an edge of unease to a goodbye with a war going on. 
 Carved on a marble slab on the courthouse lawn are the names of people who did not come back. Forty-four from Weakley County died in World War I, 98 in World War II, 9 in Korea, 17 in Vietnam. Soon nearly all 166 members of the 1174th will be going to war to back up the Fourth Infantry Division, which left Fort Hood, Tex., today. 
 Dresden is out of the way, more than a two-hour drive from Nashville and Memphis. "If you leave your lights on in Dresden," Mayor Forrester said, "someone will call and say, 'Hey, your light's on.' " Families with names like Taylor, Davis, King, Johnson and Moore stay put and proliferate. 
 With the closing of a big printing plant recently, eliminating 1,000 jobs, and layoffs of another 1,000 by a Goodyear plant nearby, Suzie German, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce and Mr. German's wife, said the economy had taken some blows. Because of the state budget deficit, Mr. Gifford, the county executive, said he was planning cuts in budget items that the state helps finance. 
 The county is historically Democratic and home of Al Gore's mother, Pauline, but like the state, it voted for President Bush over Mr. Gore in 2000. American flags have not sprouted around town as they did after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. 
Views of the war are mixed, though support for the soldiers is solid. "Women tend to have more sadness about it, that our troops have to go," Mrs. German said. 
As yet there have been no demonstrations.
 "Everybody knows everybody else's opinion, so who would you demonstrate to?" Mr. German said. 
At Fort Campbell, a two-hour drive from Dresden, Sergeant Winstead, 35, who has a 3-year-old daughter and a 1-year-old son, has been whiling away the weeks with his buddy and fellow self-employed logger Sgt. Corky King, 35, father of 11- and 13-year-old boys. Big, muscular, towheaded men, they have been sleeping in a crowded barracks, leaving just twice since Feb. 6 for weekend visits home to Dresden. 
 "We were both in Desert Storm," Sergeant King said. "We supported the First Infantry." They retired from the 1174th right after the war, but after 9/11, they rejoined. "It's something we need to do," he said. They drive trucks that haul fuel to Army trucks, tanks and Humvees on the front. In the Persian Gulf, they took turns riding shotgun, but in this war, they said, gun trucks will ride alongside. They fret about finances, but in lots of ways they say the town is helping them and their families. 
When the 1174th went off to Fort Campbell, churchwomen followed to sew patches on the troops' newly issued desert fatigues. Shops and offices around Court Square bloomed with fat, satin yellow ribbons, many distributed by the Brownies. Jennifer Tiede, a young mother in Martin, a neighboring town, is collecting $25 donations so she can make Easter baskets for the 120 children the 1174th has left behind.
 "We just love the military, all the men and women," Ceclia Nanney, 38, said. "I saw them in the sandstorm. I just cried. I got all mushy." Ms. Nanney works at Kountry Korner, a convenience store and restaurant. A brother-in-law, Terry Woodruff, and his wife, her sister, Laura Woodruff, have built the business into one of Dresden's liveliest. They also own a real estate business. 
 The Woodruffs are hands-on managers, cooking, serving, managing a staff of 20. But Mr. Woodruff is also a staff sergeant who has gone off with the 1174th, and Mrs. Woodruff has a lot to handle. "You have a job," she said. "You have to do all the jobs. There's no one to meet in the middle." 
 But the town has rallied. "I've had repairs done on the building, and I haven't received a bill," Mrs. Woodruff said. She has been calling on Phillip Davis, who mows the grass, to fix the coolers and freezers, a chore Sergeant Woodruff normally does. "I said, 'Give me a bill.' He said, 'Don't worry about it.' " Mr. German said he was keeping an eye on the Woodruffs' loans, in case they need a break.
 Mrs. Woodruff, meanwhile, is keeping an eye on another guardsman at Fort Campbell, a manager of a fast-food restaurant with five children. "He's getting about a third of his pay," she said. "So the community is getting together to be sure they're all taken care of."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Businesses in the town square of Dresden, Tenn., are decorated with yellow ribbons and bows to show support for American troops. (Billy Kingsley for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
WPP's Rating Cut But Outlook Rises

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott and Nat Ives 

 BODY:
Fitch Ratings has downgraded by one notch the debt ratings for the WPP Group in London, which owns agencies like Ogilvy & Mather, J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam. Fitch also upgraded the WPP rating outlook to stable from negative. 
 The WPP debt ratings were cut to BBB from BBB+ for senior unsecured debt. Fitch attributed the downgrading to concern over WPP's ability to repay debt, as well as the uncertain operating environment for the ad industry. The rating outlook was upgraded to stable, Fitch said, because of new-business wins and lower operating costs. 
 The changes came after Fitch made similar shifts with the ratings and outlook for the Omnicom Group in New York and after Standard & Poor's made similar changes for Omnicom and the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: FINANCIAL RATINGS (91%); CREDIT BUREAUS (91%); FINANCIAL RATING DOWNGRADES (91%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING AGENCIES (90%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING (86%) CREDIT; RATINGS AND RATING SYSTEMS 

COMPANY: WPP PLC (92%); JWT (91%); FITCH RATINGS LTD (85%); OMNICOM GROUP INC (85%); INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COS INC (84%); OGILVY & MATHER WORLDWIDE (58%)

 INTERNATIONAL A2-6

War News Summary B2

Suicide Bomber in Israel Wounds at Least 36
A Palestinian suicide bomber struck in Netanya, killing himself with a shrapnel-packed explosive and wounding three dozen people, at least six of them seriously. Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for the attack, calling the bombing a "gift" to the people of Iraq. The group also said it had sent Palestinians to Baghdad with the goal of carrying out suicide attacks against American and British soldiers. A3

Divorce Proposal in Italy
The Italian Parliament is considering a proposal that would drastically reduce the time it takes to get a divorce. The country has one of the world's highest concentrations of Roman Catholics and one of the lowest divorce rates in the European Union. Divorces can take up to 10 years before the final papers are signed. The proposal would reduce the period to one year. A6

Elections in Zimbabwe
Zimbabweans voted to elect representatives to Parliament in an atmosphere thick with political tensions between President Robert Mugabe and opposition leaders. Odds appeared to favor the main opposition party, which controls all 19 parliamentary seats from the capital area. The results were expected to be announced today. A2

Looking for Kim Jong Il
Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea, did not show up to the annual meeting of the Supreme People's Assembly of North Korea for the first time in six years. North Korea's news organizations have not reported a public appearance by Mr. Kim in 46 days. A6

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Illness Spreading in Hong Kong
Health officials in Hong Kong announced 60 more cases of a mysterious kind of pneumonia known as severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, bringing the total for the last four days to 204 -- more than the rest of the world combined, excluding mainland China, which has not yet reported any cases in March. The State Department warned that the quality of medical services in the city was being affected by the pressure of treating the illness. A3

NATIONAL A8-11

Bottom Line in Mind, Doctors Sell Ephedra
Some doctors have been actively promoting dietary supplements that include ephedra and caffeine, a combination otherwise banned for use in over-the-counter medications. The doctors' support allows marketing companies to use their names in endorsements and lobbying efforts. A8

Pivotal Suit on Libel
The Pennsylvania Supreme Court will soon decide whether the news media may report, without endorsement or skepticism, wild charges made by one politician against another. A8

Shuttle Recorder Yields Clues
Data recovered from a recorder on board the shuttle Columbia shows that abnormal heating began about a minute earlier than previously thought, in a location slightly farther out toward the wingtip. A9

Foundation Grants Held Steady
Neither volatile stock market nor weak economy nor bad investments made much of a dent in giving by foundations last year. A8

G.O.P. Moderates Show Clout
Republican moderates in Congress have begun to overturn their image as an ineffective fringe group with a series of contrarian votes. They are threatening to become an impediment to the Bush administration's domestic agenda. A11

Charity Meters Cause Discord
Seattle is installing new "giving meters" -- parking meters altered to accept spare change for the needy. But advocates for the homeless have expressed consternation that the program was introduced as a way to fight panhandling. A9

Robert E. Hudec
A professor who broadened the study of laws governing international trade to embrace matters of diplomacy and politics, he was 68. F7

Dr. Vernon W. Hughes
A Yale physicist whose investigation of particles called muons poked holes in standard subatomic theory and provided evidence for the existence of previously undetected matter, he was 81. F7

No New Stadium for Mets; Instead, Overhaul for Shea
New York City, which owns and maintains Shea Stadium, has put $19.1 million into renovating the stadium this season as the New York Mets are taking the field for their 40th season at Shea amid an economic downturn that has temporarily scuttled plans for a new ballpark. F1

Suspect in Shootings Arrested
The police have arrested a man who they believe shot and killed four shopkeepers in Brooklyn and Queens since early last month, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced. F1

SmokingBan Takes Effect
Cigarettes burned into the morning at many bars as New York City's indoor smoking ban took effect, while at others, bartenders cupped their hands, called for silence, and eulogized the days of the smoke-filled saloon. F1

Labor Dispute at Hospital
Montefiore Medical Center has become one of the most financially successful hospitals in the city, but many residents and interns say the pressure to do more with less is compromising their medical education and patient care, and they are trying to unionize. F1

The Orangemen beat the Oklahoma Sooners, 63-47, to win the N.C.A.A. east regional men's basketball championship. Syracuse pounced on the top-seeded Sooners from the opening tip and never let up. D1

Ground Zero Museum Sponsor
American Express has agreed to support a Museum of Freedom that may be built at the World Trade Center site. The museum would present exhibitions about the terrorist attacks as well as about issues like women's equality and civil rights. E3

Economy Tough on Broadway
The suddenly shaky fortunes of two multimillion-dollar theatrical productions -- the just-opened "Urban Cowboy" and the now-postponed revival of "The Miracle Worker" -- are just the latest indications of the unsettled economic state of Broadway. E1

The Guggenheim Museum will open an exhibition of works by Kasimir Malevich, a master of the Russian avant-garde, on May 13. E1

Radio Giant on the Defensive
Clear Channel Communications, so aggressively dominant as the nation's biggest radio broadcaster that some critics refer to it as the Microsoft of music, now finds itself fending off a new set of accusations: that the company is using its considerable market power to drum up support for the war in Iraq, while muzzling musicians who oppose it. C1

F.B.I. Inquiry Looks Offshore
The F.B.I. is investigating whether Richard M. Scrushy, the embattled chairman of HealthSouth, may have established offshore bank accounts as a tax haven, the agency confirmed. C1

HDTV Slowly Catches On
High-definition television, digital-quality television with a supersharp picture the shape of a movie screen, has started to catch on in measurable ways. Since its rollout in 1998, HDTV has been costly and the availability of signals on cable has been skimpy. C1

More Cuts for Airlines
US Airways plans to emerge from bankruptcy, but it still needs to cut costs and consider retooling how it makes money, the company's chief executive said. American Airlines, which is struggling to stay out of bankruptcy court, said it had reached a tentative agreement on labor concessions with six small work groups in its largest union. C2

Wartime Sales Rebound
Preliminary figures issued by Wal-Mart and Federated department stores, which include Bloomingdale's and Macy's, said that sales had slowed during the first week of the war but appeared to be recovering. C2

The Liberty Media Corporation has filed a lawsuit against Vivendi Universal, accusing it of concealing financial problems before using Vivendi stock in late 2001 to buy most of Liberty's stake in USA Networks. C5

 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 766 words

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
More Suds Than Insights In 'Rudy'

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
IT gets people out of context and scenes out of sequence. It was made in Toronto instead of New York and bungles easily checked quotations. But hey, this is television. Those inconsistencies and near-misses are nothing compared with the larger disappointment of "Rudy: The Rudy Giuliani Story," the unfortunate TV film about the former mayor of New York that debuted on USA last night and will be replayed all week.
 The real problem with "Rudy" is what it does not do. The film, directed by Robert Dornhelm, had a chance to explore the mystery of Rudolph W. Giuliani, to probe a complex political figure. It could have tried to explain the transformation inherent in the movie's tag line: "He divided a city. He united a nation." 
 How could it be that the often willfully fierce, avenging man who led New York for eight years as if he owned the place found the inner resources to get the city through its darkest hours, to give the country the reassurance it craved? It was, for Giuliani-watchers, a perplexing performance, the equivalent of watching the dark Richard M. Nixon turn into the I-feel-your-pain Bill Clinton. 
Before the terrorist attack, Mr. Giuliani nurtured so fearsome a public demeanor that as his tenure was ending, even supporters had grown impatient with him.
Then came Sept. 11, and he became Mayor of America. Once the immediate danger had passed, Mr. Giuliani reverted to type, trying unsuccessfully to stay in charge by extending his term. But when it most counted, when New Yorkers needed reassurance, guidance and candor, they got it. And they got it from the same man who seemed to court enemies as avidly as he fought crime and improved the city's reputation, with help from a strong economy.
Now this is one potentially great story. If only "Rudy" had told it, or even tried to.
Instead, the film gives Sept. 11 -- as well as the former mayor's performance in that tragedy -- a minor role, choosing to focus on Mr. Giuliani's personality. Even there, he is shown as so one-dimensional that cardboard comes to mind. Or maybe a cartoon. The Rudy in "Rudy" is a driven, ill-tempered man who uses obscenities, refers to New York as "my city," and is insensitive to those closest to him.
He is intolerant when the demands of her career make his wife, Donna Hanover, inattentive to him. The film has him turning to his communications director, Cristyne F. Lategano (now Cristyne L. Nicholas), for help and support and maybe a personal relationship, which both have denied. Then he pays her off with a good job when he unceremoniously dumps her for Judith Nathan, now his fiancee.
SOME of the timing is off, but the scenes draw on what was an uncomfortable public unraveling of Mr. Giuliani's marriage. The awkward revelations about his personal life, which came at the same time that the public learned about his prostate cancer, were the stuff of soap opera -- irresistible to Hollywood (or Toronto). 
But what about the rest? The metamorphosis of Mr. Giuliani is all but ignored, the subtleties missing. Predictably, the film even fumbles what history will surely record as the most eloquent remark of the former mayor's career. In the hours after the attack on the twin towers, Mr. Giuliani declined to estimate the death toll, instead saying in a halting voice, "The number of casualties will be more than any of us can bear." In the film, the actor James Woods intones, "The loss of life is greater than any of us can possibly bear." (Oddly, this line is also misquoted in the former mayor's own book, "Leadership.")
The thought is the same, but the altered quotation gets the sentiment wrong. As does so much of the film, written by Stanley Weiser from the investigative biography of Mr. Giuliani by Wayne Barrett of The Village Voice. The only moments in "Rudy" that give the mayor some emotional depth are those showing him going to funerals and comforting a friend and aide who lost her husband on Sept. 11.
Just a film, right? But it is through movies and television that most people get what passes for reality now. The public gets some of its war news through televised briefings with White House advisers. Candidates wage campaigns in paid political ads. Filmmakers pretend to teach history through movies that spin conspiracy theories, like Oliver Stone's "J.F.K.," or turn ancient Rome into flashy vehicles for stars like Russell Crowe.
"Rudy" might have given New Yorkers revealing insights into the man who helped get them through the trauma of Sept. 11, 2001. Instead, the best thing to be said about this film is that it leaves plenty of room for the next one. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Metro Matters column on Monday about the television film "Rudy: The Rudy Giuliani Story" misidentified the city where it was made. It was Montreal, not Toronto.
